company.entity_resolution_notes: Proff identifies the entity as 7 STEEL NORDIC MANUFACTURING AS with org.nr 953 591 421 [1]. LEI data tied to Brønnøysund registration ID 953 591 421 lists CELSA ARMERINGSSTÅL AS as a previous legal name, supporting continuity after renaming [5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: The company uses ferrous steel scrap as core inbound feedstock for electric-arc-furnace steelmaking; sources describe scrap-based production and annual recycling volumes above 700,000 tonnes [2][3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Ferrous steel scrap
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as the main metallic feedstock in electric arc furnace steel production at Mo i Rana [2][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence describes steel production based on scrap metal and reports more than 700,000 tonnes of scrap recycled per year, indicating this is core rather than pilot use [3][4].

main_quantity.context: A public statement about Celsa Armeringsstål (previous legal name linked to same registration ID) reports annual recycling of over 700,000 tonnes of scrap metal [3][5].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The quantified figure is stated as "over 700 000 tonn" and not tied to a specific reporting year in the source text [3]. EPD text confirms scrap-based steelmaking inputs but does not provide audited annual tonnes for the legal entity [4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: No directly accessed annual/sustainability report for this exact legal entity provided a current-year audited SRM input mass; quantity therefore relies on a press release statement and supporting EPD process description [3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No source found in this review provided a legal-entity-specific audited breakdown of scrap grades or monthly inbound SRM tonnage [3][4].
EPD evidence is tied to downstream products and references supplier process data from 7 Steel Nordic Manufacturing, so volume attribution to the legal entity is supported but indirect [4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Nesseplast publicly describes EPS as its main raw material and states that EPS is oil-based. Reviewed website pages and a product declaration emphasize product/material recyclability and reuse potential, but no evidence in the reviewed sources confirms inbound use of secondary raw materials (such as reprocessed/recycled EPS feedstock) [2][3][4].
gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed public pages and the sampled product declaration do not state whether any recycled/reprocessed EPS or other SRM is used as an inbound input [2][3][4].
No public quantitative data (mass, share, or annual volume) on SRM input use was identified in the reviewed sources [2][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: AKVA group discloses inbound SRM use in its 2024 annual report, including reintegrated plastic scrap in pipe production at Helgeland Plast (289 tons, about 60% of generated scrap), recycled HDPE in pen/floating-unit solutions, and recycled nylon feedstock for circular farming nets [2]. Only the Helgeland Plast plastic loop is quantified with an absolute annual mass [2].

srm_inputs.label: Reintegrated plastic scrap in pipe production (Helgeland Plast)
srm_inputs.used_for: AKVA states that scrap generated at Helgeland Plast is reintegrated into pipe production, indicating internal recycled plastic used as a production input [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company reports both an annual mass (289 tons) and a reintegration rate (about 60% of generated scrap), which supports meaningful SRM use at business-unit level rather than a pilot [2].

main_quantity.context: The 2024 annual report quantifies reintegrated scrap at Helgeland Plast as 289 tons for the year [2].

share.context: The reported share is about 60% of scrap generated at Helgeland Plast that is reintegrated into pipe production [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: This is the only reviewed AKVA disclosure with a direct annual SRM input mass (tons) [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The cited text does not specify polymer grade or the share of total pipe-production input represented by the reintegrated scrap [2].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled HDPE for floating units and pen solutions
srm_inputs.used_for: AKVA reports recycled HDPE use in floating elements replacing EPS in Chile floating units for steel pens, and it also tested a fully recycled pen made from HDPE sourced from discarded pens [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The Chile disclosure indicates implemented substitution (including a 2024 no-polystyrene statement in that context), while the fully recycled HDPE pen remains test-stage; together this supports meaningful use in a defined scope but without disclosed volumes [2].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No mass, recycled-content percentage, or annual procurement volume for recycled HDPE is disclosed in the reviewed report excerpts [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The disclosures are product/geography specific, and the report does not quantify how much recycled HDPE was used across AKVA overall or separate the Chile and test-pen volumes [2].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled nylon for circular farming nets
srm_inputs.used_for: AKVA describes development of circular farming nets using recycled nylon sourced from used nets, fishing gear, and other nylon products, and reports producing the first recycled net [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The evidence shows early implementation (first recycled net produced) with sea testing planned for 2025, which is consistent with pilot-stage SRM input use rather than broad rollout [2].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: The reviewed disclosure does not provide tonnage, annual purchasing volume, or input share for recycled nylon used in nets [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Commercial scale, repeat frequency, and ongoing recycled-nylon input volumes are not quantified in the cited 2024 annual report text [2].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Only one SRM input stream (Helgeland Plast reintegrated plastic scrap) is quantified with an absolute annual mass; other disclosed SRM uses are qualitative or pilot/deployment statements without volume data [2].
The recycled HDPE disclosures confirm use in specific products/geographies but do not provide company-wide totals or recycled-content percentages for aggregation [2].
The circular farming net disclosure confirms recycled nylon sourcing and first production, but not recurring annual input volumes or shares [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Alcoa Norway AS shows evidence of inbound recycled metal input (remelt/scrap-derived aluminum) used in production. The annual report states remelt metal is added/mixed in production, and Mosjøen products include at least 50% recycled content for EcoDura-standard cast products [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled/remelt aluminum metal input
srm_inputs.used_for: Remelt/recycled aluminum is used as an inbound metal input in casting/alloy production; the report says remelt metal is added to primary production and mixed with potroom metal [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates regular operational use (not only pilot): remelt metal is part of production flows, and Mosjøen states EcoDura cast products with at least 50% recycled content [2][3].

share.context: The EcoDura requirement states at least 50% recycled content in the aluminum product; this is product-standard evidence, not company-wide average [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No public source found with company-level annual tonnage of inbound recycled/remelt metal for Alcoa Norway AS; available evidence is qualitative plus a product-level minimum share [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 50% recycled-content figure applies to EcoDura-standard cast products and does not disclose what share of total Alcoa Norway output this represents [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No disclosed company-level mass flow (t/year) for inbound recycled/remelt aluminum was identified in the reviewed public sources [2][3].
No source in scope quantified site-by-site split (Lista vs Mosjøen) of recycled metal input volumes [2][3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity was used as instructed; accessible sources refer to the facility/company as Aludyne Norway / Aludyne Norway AS, and no conflicting identity information was observed during SRM research [1][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: A 2021 environmental inspection report for Aludyne Norway AS states the site used 4,000 tonnes of aluminum scrap in 2020 as part of its aluminum raw-material input and cites a goal to exceed 70% recycled aluminum by 2025 [3]. Aludyne's sustainability page also describes use of secondary smelters and high recycled content in castings, but those statements are group-level context rather than Norway-site-specific evidence [2].

srm_inputs.label: Aluminum scrap (recycled aluminum)
srm_inputs.used_for: The Farsund operation is listed as light-metal casting, and the inspection report states the company uses only aluminum as raw material while including aluminum scrap in that input mix [3][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The site reported actual use of 4,000 t aluminum scrap in 2020. The same report also states about 16,000 t aluminum raw material per year, implying an inferred scrap share of roughly 25%, which indicates meaningful but not dominant SRM input use [3].

main_quantity.context: Inspection report states the site used 4,000 tonnes of aluminum scrap in 2020 [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct SRM quantity is available (4,000 t aluminum scrap in 2020). The report also states about 16,000 t aluminum raw material per year, which is useful context for scale but is not an SRM-only quantity [3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The quantified scrap-input evidence is from a 2021 inspection report describing 2020 use, and no newer site-level scrap tonnage was identified in accessible sources during this run [3][5].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The pre-matched norskeutslipp permit PDF endpoint was available as input, but its text could not be extracted in this run, so evidence relies on an accessible inspection report and company website content instead [2][5].
Aludyne's sustainability page provides useful context on secondary aluminum sourcing and recycled content, but it is not explicitly scoped to the Norway entity/site [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed sources confirm Atlantic Styro is an EPS/styropor producer, but no company-specific evidence was found that recycled, recovered, or waste-derived materials are used as inbound inputs. The sector EPD covering Atlantic Styro discusses PS-bead raw-material transport and mentions recycled EPS in Module D (end-of-life substitution), not as a documented inbound input to Atlantic Styro [1][2][3].
gaps_and_uncertainties: No Atlantic Styro primary source (website, product sheet, or report) describing recycled input content was located among the reviewed materials, so inbound SRM use could be underreported [1][2][3].
The EPD is a multi-manufacturer declaration and supports sector/product assumptions rather than Atlantic Styro-specific SRM shares or tonnages [2].

An Atlas Copco case study documents closed-loop seal-water recirculation in production equipment, but it does not evidence recycled polymer feedstock use and was treated here as internal utility recirculation rather than SRM input [3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Baca's website gives direct evidence of recycled plastic being used as an inbound production input: sack products are described as produced from collected, recycled plastic raw material, and the company states plastic waste/residuals are regenerated and used in new products [2][3]. This supports meaningful SRM input use in plastic production, but no company-wide quantities or shares are disclosed [2][3].

material_examples: plastic offcuts/residuals reused in new production
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as input material in sack production and other plastic products; the company describes sacks produced from collected recycled plastic raw material and regenerated plastic used in new products [2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The evidence describes ongoing commercial production use on product and environment pages (not pilot testing), but the company does not publish company-wide recycled-input volumes or overall percentages [2][3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct mass, volume, energy, or percentage figures for recycled plastic inputs were identified on the reviewed Baca pages [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The sources do not separate internally regenerated plastic (from own waste/offcuts) from externally sourced recycled plastic raw material, and no annual intake figures are provided [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-level annual quantity of recycled plastic input (e.g., tonnes/year) was found on the reviewed pages [2][3].
No company-wide recycled-content share across total production was disclosed; evidence is qualitative and product/process oriented [2][3].
The relative contribution of internal reprocessing versus externally sourced recycled polymer feedstock is not quantified [2][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: BEFORM publicly states that it uses recycled raw materials and describes recycling different raw materials into new products at its production sites, including internal production material and products collected from clients; it also describes internal recycling and reuse in production, but no company-level input volumes are disclosed on the reviewed pages.[3][4][5]

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed thermoplastic materials (regrind / recycled plastic feedstock)
material_examples: Recycled thermoplastic material from waste/closed-loop sources
srm_inputs.used_for: BEFORM describes using recycled plastic materials in production, including processing/injection moulding and reuse of received products for the same type of products, sometimes mixed with virgin material.[3][4][5]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates ongoing operational use (not only pilot language): BEFORM describes current recycling at production sites, internal recycling facilities, and reuse of received products in production, including complete or partial use with virgin material. However, no quantitative scale is disclosed.[4][5]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No public mass/volume input figures were identified in the reviewed BEFORM pages. The pages provide qualitative process descriptions and a case-level statement that received products may be reused completely (100%) or partially mixed with virgin material, but not a company-wide feedstock share.[4][5]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The reviewed sources do not quantify annual recycled polymer input, site-by-site split, or the proportion of total polymer feedstock that is recycled versus virgin. They also do not clearly separate internal scrap reuse from externally returned material volumes.[4][5]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-level annual tonnage of recycled plastic input was identified on the reviewed BEFORM website pages.[4][5]

The evidence is based on company website statements and process descriptions; no third-party verified recycled-content percentages or product-level EPD figures were identified in the reviewed sources.[3][4][5]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity fields were retained as provided [1]. An official BENTELER press release explicitly names BENTELER Automotive Raufoss AS, while the Norske utslipp listing is for Benteler Automotive Raufoss and links the permit used here [2][3]. The linked permit itself is a 2008 permit issued to Hydro Aluminium Structures Raufoss AS at Fabrikkvn. 2 / Raufoss Industripark, so it is treated as predecessor-site process context rather than direct legal-entity proof for org. no. 994344552 [4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: BENTELER Automotive Raufoss AS has clear evidence of inbound secondary aluminum scrap use (A3): the company states a ~40% recycled aluminum share at its Norwegian site and explicitly mentions increasing external and post-consumer scrap use in the Raufoss casthouse context [2]. Historical permit data for the same site supports that the operation is an aluminum foundry/profile production site with secondary aluminum classification, but it is under a predecessor name [4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminum scrap (external and post-consumer)
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as aluminum input in the Raufoss in-house casthouse / extrusion-based production of automotive aluminum components; the company states increased use of external and post-consumer scrap at the site [2]. Historical permit text also describes aluminum profile production and foundry operations at the same site [4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The Raufoss site reports approximately 40% recycled aluminum use and planned increase to 50%, and explicitly describes increasing external and post-consumer scrap with infrastructure expanded for scrap handling, indicating SRM use is significant to site production [2]. Historical permit context (secondary aluminum classification and large foundry capacity) supports a high-scale aluminum process at this location, though under a predecessor entity [4].

share.context: Reported as the share of recycled aluminum used at the Norwegian site (and discussed as recycled content in products) after the Raufoss casthouse modernization; not explicitly split into inbound external vs internal recycled material [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No tonnes/year of inbound external or post-consumer scrap were disclosed in the sources used. The available quantified figure is a percentage share of recycled aluminum (40%). The 55,000 t/year figure in the permit is historical foundry capacity, not a disclosed SRM input volume [2][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The reported recycled aluminum share may include internal process scrap recycling (e.g., extrusion waste) in addition to inbound SRM scrap; the source does not quantify the external/post-consumer portion separately [2]. Permit-based scale/context evidence is from a 2008 permit issued to a predecessor company at the same site [4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No source in this run discloses actual annual tonnes of external or post-consumer aluminum scrap entering the Raufoss site; only recycled-share percentages are stated [2].

The available Norske utslipp permit document for this site is a predecessor-company permit (Hydro Aluminium Structures Raufoss AS), so permit-derived process/capacity details are treated as historical site context [3][4].
Although the company description mentions plastic-based parts, no evidence was found in this run for recycled plastic (A4) input use at the Norwegian site [1][2].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity fields were retained from the task metadata [5]. Reviewed sources consistently reference BEWI Fredrikstad / Sørkilen 3 operations with no clear discrepancy versus the provided company context [1][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence shows meaningful inbound use of recycled plastic (polystyrene/EPS/XPS) at BEWI’s Fredrikstad insulation operations: a permitted EPS recycling/reuse activity for own production, a new integrated recycling facility with stated capacity up to 3,500 tonnes/year, Terra XPS with 45% recycled raw material, and a Greenline EPS EPD declaring recycled raw material input [1][2][3][4]. Company-wide annual SRM input tonnage/share across all products is not disclosed in the reviewed sources [2][3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled EPS feedstock for Fredrikstad recycling and insulation production
srm_inputs.used_for: BEWI’s Fredrikstad site receives used EPS (including insulation and packaging), processes it (granulation/mechanical processing), and uses the resulting recycled material as raw material for new insulation products; the permit announcement confirms EPS recycling/reuse for own production [1][2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: A dedicated recycling facility at the Fredrikstad production site and a stated annual capacity up to 3,500 tonnes indicate meaningful SRM use, but the source provides capacity rather than verified annual throughput [2].

main_quantity.context: BEWI states the Fredrikstad EPS recycling plant has annual recycling capacity of up to 3,500 tonnes; this is a stated plant capacity, not confirmed realized input volume [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The available site-level number is a stated annual recycling capacity (up to 3,500 tonnes) from BEWI’s press release, not measured inbound SRM throughput [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Actual annual inbound SRM use at Fredrikstad may differ from capacity, especially during ramp-up; the public permit announcement confirms scope (EPS for own production) but not realized tonnage [1][2].

srm_inputs.label: Recovered EPS/XPS in Terra XPS insulation boards
srm_inputs.used_for: Terra XPS insulation board production uses recovered EPS and XPS as part of the raw-material mix (recycled plastic feedstock) [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The product sheet explicitly states that 45% of Terra XPS raw material is recovered EPS/XPS, which indicates meaningful SRM use in that product line [3].

share.context: BEWI’s Terra XPS product sheet states that 45% of the raw material used is recovered EPS and XPS [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No per-year mass of recycled EPS/XPS input is disclosed for Terra XPS in the reviewed product sheet; only a feedstock share is given [3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: This share is product-specific (Terra XPS) and cannot be translated into company-wide inbound SRM tonnage without production volume data [3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastic raw material in Greenline EPS (Fredrikstad)
srm_inputs.used_for: The Greenline EPS product for Fredrikstad uses recycled plastic as inbound raw material in insulation board production; the EPD states the product is made of recycled raw material and provides declared-unit composition data [4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The EPD explicitly states Greenline EPS is made of 100% recycled raw material and shows recycled plastic dominating the declared-unit material composition, indicating SRM is core to this product [4].

other_quantities.context: The EPD materials table for the declared unit lists "Plastic - Recycled" at 0.60 kg [4].

share.context: The EPD materials table reports recycled plastic as 94.79% in the declared-unit composition table [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Quantification is provided per EPD declared unit (product composition), not as annual site consumption of recycled plastic [4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The EPD is product-specific and does not disclose Greenline EPS production volume at Fredrikstad, so annual inbound SRM tonnage cannot be derived from this source alone [4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The reviewed public permit announcement confirms EPS recycling/reuse scope and own-production use, but detailed permit clauses and any numeric permit limits were not extracted from the permit document here [1].
Available quantification mixes site-level capacity (3,500 t/year) and product-level composition shares (45% Terra XPS; 94.79% Greenline EPD table), which are not additive [2][3][4].
No company-wide split of recycled versus virgin polymer inputs across all BEWI Insulation Norge AS products/activities was found in the reviewed sources [2][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: BEWI sources provide qualitative evidence that recycled polymer feedstock is used in EPS packaging products (including fish boxes via Circulum Balance / recycled EPS), but the reviewed disclosures are at product/group level and do not quantify inbound SRM use for BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS specifically [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled polymer feedstock for EPS packaging
material_examples: Recycled EPS used in fish boxes
srm_inputs.used_for: BEWI describes Circulum Balance as EPS based on recycled feedstock suitable for food contact packaging, and reports launching EPS fish boxes based on recycled EPS; the press release also states GreenLine fish boxes use Circulum Balance based on recycled feedstock [2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The evidence supports inbound recycled plastic/polymer feedstock use in BEWI packaging products, but it does not provide a legal-entity-specific quantity or share for BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS, so the entity-level assessment remains T1 [2][3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct inbound tonnage or legal-entity-specific share was found for BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS in the reviewed sources; the annual report only provides a group-level recycled/renewable materials share KPI [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The reviewed evidence is product/group scoped, and the annual report explicitly states environmental KPIs are for total operations, so allocation to org. no. 928878090 is not explicit [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The reviewed annual report and press release do not disclose BEWI PACKAGING NORWAY AS-specific inbound recycled-EPS tonnage or percentage share [2][3].
The annual report's recycled/renewable material share KPI is reported for total operations (group scope), which limits entity-level attribution [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: BIR Ressurs AS uses incoming residual waste as a core waste-derived fuel input in its waste-to-energy operations; the company reports receiving about 200,000 tons in 2024 and converting combustion energy into heat and power [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Residual waste used as solid waste-derived fuel
material_examples: Selected combustible fractions including some hazardous fractions permitted for treatment
srm_inputs.used_for: Incoming residual waste is combusted in the Rådalen plant, where released energy is used to produce steam for electricity and district heating [2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is core to operations: the company states it received about 200,000 tons of waste in 2024 and runs large-scale continuous combustion-based energy recovery [2][3].

main_quantity.context: Company reporting states approximately 200,000 tons of waste were received in 2024 at the plant [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The disclosed volume is approximate ("ca.") and reported as total incoming waste, not a fully disaggregated SRF specification by fraction [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Sources do not provide a precise split of inbound waste by composition (e.g., biogenic/fossil share, specific combustible sub-fractions), so B1 classification is based on residual waste-to-energy context [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No source found in reviewed material with audited, fraction-level inbound SRM breakdown for BIR Ressurs AS (by waste type and exact SRF composition) [2][3].
No direct permit document with explicit annual input limit/actuals was retrieved; the annual-report page references permit scope at a high level [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed Bluegreen Group sustainability and project pages describe PE/polyethylene materials and recyclability/end-of-life recycling, but they do not provide explicit evidence that recycled/recovered secondary raw materials are used as inbound inputs in Bluegreen Fusion's production or activities [2][3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Prefilled identity details are consistent with the opened Proff record for BRUKET AS (org. 924363304) in Åbogen, and the discovered company website content aligns with aluminium-railing production activity [1][2][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Bruket AS clearly uses aluminium-related inputs in its production (e.g., aluminium profiles from Hydro), but the reviewed company pages only document low-carbon aluminium and general aluminium recyclability claims, not concrete use of recycled/recovered/waste-derived inputs by Bruket itself [2][3]. Two checked pre-matched norskeutslipp permits were for unrelated Moelven wood-processing facilities, so they do not provide SRM-input evidence for Bruket AS [4][5].
gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed company pages confirm aluminium procurement and production activity, but do not disclose recycled content share, post-consumer scrap use, or any waste-derived feedstock in Bruket's inbound inputs [2][3].
The FAQ mentions reuse of aluminium scrap as a general material property; it does not state that Bruket purchases recycled aluminium profiles or other SRM inputs [3].
Sampled pre-matched norskeutslipp permits belong to Moelven facilities (Østerdalsbruket and Soknabruket), indicating noisy name-based permit matching for this company [4][5].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity data was used as instructed. No genuine discrepancy was identified; reviewed Carpenter materials are consistent with the Åndalsnes site context for Carpenter AS [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: No site-specific evidence confirming recycled, recovered, reused, or waste-derived inbound inputs at Carpenter AS (Åndalsnes) was found in the reviewed sources. The reviewed local documents describe foam/mattress production and conventional chemical inputs (including TDI), and mention ISCC PLUS/circularity work without confirming actual SRM input use or volumes at the Norwegian site [2][3][4].
gaps_and_uncertainties: The Åndalsnes location page lists `ISCC PLUS` under certifications, but the page itself does not specify certified material categories, recycled content, or volumes [2].

Local Carpenter AS documents describe chemical-based production inputs and mention ISCC PLUS process/traceability, but they do not explicitly confirm current inbound SRM use at the Åndalsnes site [3][4].

A circular-economy statement in the transparency report refers to products being recycled after end of life, which is an outflow/downstream circularity statement rather than evidence of inbound SRM input use [4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: No material discrepancy found in the pre-filled identity: Proff matches the legal name and organization number, while the company website evidence is presented at group level and notes multiple subsidiaries (important boundary context for SRM attribution) [1][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Cinderella Eco product pages provide evidence of recycled plastic content in several accessory products (recycled PP and 50% recycled ABS), indicating inbound SRM use in product materials, but only at product level with no company-wide quantities disclosed [2][3][4]. The reviewed website evidence is group/brand-facing and does not clearly allocate these inputs to CINDERELLA ECO GROUP AS specifically [1].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastics in accessory products
srm_inputs.used_for: Product pages describe accessory items (air inlet grate, transport cap, and stop valve) as made of recycled PP plastic or 50% recycled ABS plastic, indicating recycled polymer input use in those products [2][3][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence shows repeated recycled-content claims across multiple accessory product pages, but no annual inbound volume, no procurement totals, and no clear legal-entity allocation from the group-level website evidence [1][2][3][4].

share.context: The transport cap product page states the item is made from 50% recycled ABS plastic; this is treated as a product-level recycled-content share [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Reviewed product pages provide recycled-content statements but no direct mass, volume, or annual consumption figures for recycled plastics [2][3][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The website describes a group with multiple subsidiaries, so the product-page statements cannot be confidently assigned to input purchases of CINDERELLA ECO GROUP AS alone; the pages also do not quantify how material-significant these accessories are versus core products [1][2][3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Public evidence reviewed here supports recycled-content claims for specific products, but not company-level inbound SRM tonnage or annual purchased quantities [2][3][4].
Group-level website structure and subsidiary references limit precise attribution of the observed recycled-plastic inputs to the legal entity CINDERELLA ECO GROUP AS [1].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed public sources provide limited evidence of inbound SRM use, but a Cinderella product page explicitly states an air inlet grate is made of recycled PP plastic. No company-level SRM quantities or shares were disclosed in the reviewed sources [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled polypropylene (PP) plastic
srm_inputs.used_for: A Cinderella product page describes an air inlet grate component for the toilet and states that it is made of recycled PP plastic, indicating recycled polymer input in at least one component/product item [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Current evidence is limited to a single product-component material statement without company-wide procurement volumes, recycled-content shares, or broader portfolio coverage, so the supported SRM use is minor/isolated rather than meaningful at company scale [2][3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct quantity (mass/volume) or percentage share for recycled PP input is disclosed on the identified product page or the reviewed company background page [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The recycled-material claim is on a group product webpage and does not specify whether the component is manufactured directly by the legal entity CINDERELLA ECO PRODUCTION AS versus sourced within the group. No entity-level material purchasing data was found in the reviewed sources [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No annual report, sustainability/ESG report, or permit document is included among the sources used for this assessment, so quantitative SRM input evidence is missing [1][2][3].
The reviewed sources do not disclose total material mix, recycled-content share across products, or inbound SRM volumes for the Furuflaten/Lyngen production activities [2][3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Proff identifies the Norwegian legal entity as ELKEM ASA with org number 911 382 008, matching the requested company. [1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence indicates pilot/early-stage inbound SRM use: Elkem describes projects to recycle slag/silicon side streams into new products and to capture/reuse process carbon as reductant; both are framed as R&D/pilot initiatives. [2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled slag and secondary silicon streams
srm_inputs.used_for: Elkem states a 2025-2026 project to develop products by recycling slag and silicon materials, including cement alternatives and introducing recycled material streams into production. [2]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes this as funded R&D with pilot testing and demonstration, not mature large-scale disclosed use. [2]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No actual annual inbound tonnage is disclosed for recycled slag/silicon inputs; only project scope and target language (e.g., >50% recycling share in newly developed products). [2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Disclosed figures are project targets and development-phase statements; company-wide realised SRM input volumes are not reported in the cited source. [2]

srm_inputs.label: Captured process carbon reused as reductant (Sicalo pilot)
srm_inputs.used_for: Elkem describes a concept where carbon in off-gases is captured and reused in silicon production as reduction material. [3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The source explicitly says this is a pilot in Kristiansand and that substantial research remains before full-scale viability. [3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No disclosed mass/energy quantity for captured carbon reused as input; status is pilot/lab/bench scale. [3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Commercial-scale implementation timeline and actual recurring input volume are not disclosed in the cited announcement. [3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No source located here provides audited annual quantities of inbound SRM (t, kg, m3, or energy units) for ELKEM ASA. [2][3]
Elkem policy text indicates current biocarbon use is primarily wood-based while recycled wood is being explored, so biocarbon was not counted as confirmed SRM input in this assessment. [4]
Several cited activities are project or pilot descriptions; evidence of routine, company-wide SRM throughput is limited. [2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Proff record used is a site page (AVD PORSGRUNN) but it explicitly points to “Hovedenhet ERAMET NORWAY AS” with org. no. 980 518 647; Brønnøysund confirms ERAMET NORWAY AS with the same organisation number [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Eramet Norway shows evidence of inbound secondary inputs through internal recirculation of metallurgical by-products: ferromanganese slag is used as raw material for silicomanganese production, and furnace dust/slag are reintroduced into production processes [3][4][5]. Evidence indicates meaningful operational use, but no disclosed annual inbound SRM tonnage [3][4][5].

srm_inputs.label: Internal recirculation of ferromanganese slag and furnace dust
srm_inputs.used_for: Ferromanganese slag is used as an input in silicomanganese production in Kvinesdal, and furnace dust/slag are reintroduced into production processes [3][4][5].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Company and group disclosures describe slag as an “important input factor” and state that large quantities of by-products are internally circulated/reintroduced, indicating ongoing meaningful use rather than isolated pilots [4][5].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual mass/energy quantity for inbound recirculated slag or furnace dust is disclosed in the reviewed public sources [3][4][5].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Available disclosures are qualitative and do not separate exact inbound SRM volumes by site/year; therefore tiering is based on wording about operational importance and internal circulation [4][5].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Public sources reviewed do not provide a numeric annual inbound quantity (t/year) for recirculated FeMn slag or furnace dust [3][4][5].
Disclosures mix site-level and company-level narratives, limiting precise allocation of SRM input volumes to legal-entity totals [4][5].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity was resolved as EVERZINC NORWAY AS (AS) in Larvik with organization number 967337897 on Proff.[1] The Norwegian emissions registry page for companyID 5707 also identifies the facility as EverZinc Norway in Larvik.[4]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence indicates inbound use of secondary zinc-bearing materials for EverZinc operations, including material streams explicitly linked to the Larvik plant and municipal hearing text stating the Larvik facility processes scrap zinc for zinc recovery.[2][3] However, the quantified 40% secondary share is stated at EverZinc level and not isolated to the Norwegian entity.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Secondary zinc residues and scrap zinc
srm_inputs.used_for: These secondary zinc materials are purchased as inbound raw materials and used in EverZinc plants including Larvik; Larvik is described as processing scrap zinc for zinc recovery and producing zinc powder/zinc oxide.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes itself as a major recycler/consumer of galvanizing residues and states secondary raw materials are used in plants including Larvik, indicating meaningful operational use rather than pilot use.[2]

share.context: EverZinc states that 40% of zinc units processed come from secondary sources, but this is presented at EverZinc level and not broken out for Norway.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No Norway-entity-specific annual tonnage of inbound secondary zinc residues/scrap was found in the accessible sources; only a group-level secondary share statement was found.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 40% figure appears group-wide. Available Norwegian public pages confirm scrap-zinc processing in Larvik but do not provide site-specific inbound SRM mass/energy quantities.[2][3][4]

gaps_and_uncertainties: The accessible Norwegian emissions registry page confirms permits/control reports exist, but no directly accessible permit text with explicit inbound SRM tonnages was retrieved in this search session.[4]
Current evidence is sufficient for directionality (SRM inbound), but insufficient for robust Norway-only quantification beyond qualitative usage and one group-level percentage.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled legal entity data is retained. Official permits use a facility/bedrift organization number (972148172), while the climate quota permit also states owner org number 957779808, which matches the pre-filled legal entity. The permit also lists facility NACE 24.102, which differs from the pre-filled 24.100 and is likely a facility-level classification difference [1][2][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Official permit documents show multiple by-product/recycled inputs used in smelting furnaces: purchased HC slag (listed as a furnace additive and categorized as a large monitored source stream), own-produced HC slag reused as furnace additive (de-minimis), and manganese-containing sludge/water-treatment sludge reused in furnaces, with a permit allowance of 6,000 t/year for manganese sludge treatment as a manganese source [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Purchased HC slag used as furnace additive
srm_inputs.used_for: The climate quota monitoring plan lists purchased HC slag as an additive material for smelting furnaces (smelteovner) [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The purchased HC slag stream is explicitly monitored as a furnace additive and categorized as "Stor" in the climate quota monitoring plan, indicating established and meaningful use, although no public tonnage is provided in the reviewed document [3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual mass or energy quantity for purchased HC slag was identified in the reviewed permit pages; only the monitored source-stream classification is shown [3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The reviewed source confirms existence and furnace use of purchased HC slag, but not supplier origin, composition split, or actual annual consumption volume [3].

srm_inputs.label: Own-produced HC slag reused as furnace additive
srm_inputs.used_for: The climate quota monitoring plan lists own-produced HC slag as an additive material for smelting furnaces [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The stream is explicitly listed for furnaces but categorized as "De-minimis" in the monitoring plan, which supports minor rather than meaningful use in the reviewed documentation [3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct quantity is disclosed for own-produced HC slag reuse in the reviewed climate quota permit pages [3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: This is an internal reuse stream (not externally purchased), and the reviewed source does not disclose mass throughput or time-series usage [3].

srm_inputs.label: Manganese-containing sludge reused in furnaces
srm_inputs.used_for: The pollution permit states manganese-containing sludge (own waste) can be added to the furnaces as a manganese source, and the climate quota monitoring plan lists sludge from the water treatment plant as a furnace-related source stream [2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: This is an established reuse route because the permit explicitly authorizes furnace addition of manganese sludge and sets a 6,000 t/year treatment allowance, while the climate quota monitoring plan also includes water-treatment sludge as a monitored furnace source stream ("Mindre") [2][3].

main_quantity.context: The reviewed pollution permit table (section 9.1.1) gives an annual amount of 6,000 tonnes for manganese-containing sludge, described as added as a manganese source in smelting furnaces; this is a permit allowance, not confirmed actual use [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct quantity is available only as a permit limit (6,000 t/year) under treatment of own waste; the reviewed sources do not publish realized annual sludge input to furnaces [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The permit and monitoring plan confirm the reuse pathway, but the reviewed documents do not state actual annual usage versus the permitted cap, nor a detailed sludge composition split [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The reviewed official permits confirm SRM-type furnace inputs (HC slag and sludge streams), but they do not provide public annual consumption masses for the HC slag streams in the visible sections reviewed [2][3].
The 6,000 t/year value for manganese sludge is a permit allowance in section 9.1.1 and should not be treated as reported actual usage without separate operational reporting [2][3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The matched Norwegian legal entity is FORESTIA AS (Aksjeselskap) with org number 981 393 961 on Proff, consistent with the Braskereidfoss industrial operation.[1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Forestia shows evidence of inbound secondary bio-based input use: wood by-products/waste-derived chips from sawmills used in chipboard production, indicating core relevance to production.[2][3] Forestia also has an ongoing return-wood project (demolition wood cleaning/reuse) supported by public funding, but operational volumes are not disclosed.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Sawmill by-product wood chips
srm_inputs.used_for: Forestia states it procures wood as by-products from sawmills for board production, and group reporting states these chips are used in chipboards.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is described as "large amounts" and directly tied to chipboard production, indicating a core production input rather than pilot use.[2][3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No Forestia-specific annual tonnage of inbound sawmill by-product chips is disclosed in the identified public sources.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: One statement is group-level (Byggma) and may not isolate Forestia volumes; however, Forestia-specific text confirms by-product sourcing.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Return wood (demolition wood) for new chipboard feedstock
srm_inputs.used_for: Forestia reports an ongoing project to clean demolition wood and recycle it into new boards/chipboard feedstock.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates an ongoing investment/project phase with support funding, but no confirmed steady-state operational input volume is provided.[2][3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: Available figures describe project support (MNOK 80) rather than measured annual inbound mass/volume of return wood.[3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Sources do not confirm actual annual processed return-wood quantities or the exact commissioning/operational status of the line.[2][3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No public Forestia-specific annual quantity (t, m3) for inbound secondary raw materials was found in the reviewed sources.[2][3]
No disclosed share of secondary inputs versus total wood feedstock was found.[2][3]
Project evidence for demolition wood is strong, but operational throughput and year-specific realized use remain undisclosed.[2][3]

employees.notes: The accessible Proff page is for an underenhet ("GLASOPOR AS AVD OSLO") and shows "Ansatte 5"; a confirmed company-level headcount was not found in available sources. [1]

revenue.notes: Proff reports "Sum driftsinntekter 2024" as 138 458 with "Beløp i 1000", interpreted as NOK 138,458,000. [1]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Entity resolved as the Norwegian company Glasopor AS (org.nr 884344662). Proff shows the org number and an underenhet label, while permit application documents use the same organization number for Glasopor AS. [1][2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Glasopor AS uses recycled glass waste as a core inbound feedstock for foam-glass production. Permit documentation states receipt of recycled glass streams and ~55,000 tonnes in 2022 at Onsøy, while company material pages state 100% recycled glass packaging feedstock. [2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled glass feedstock
srm_inputs.used_for: Recycled glass is crushed to fine powder and heat-processed (with activator) to produce foam glass used as lightweight fill and insulation material. [2]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is described as fundamental to the product (foam glass made from recycled packaging glass), with substantial inbound quantity disclosed for Onsøy (about 55,000 t in 2022). [2][3]

main_quantity.context: The permit application states the Onsøy facility received about 55,000 tonnes of glass in 2022; this is a site-level inbound SRM amount. [2]

share.context: Company product information states foam glass is made from 100% recycled glass packaging; treated as feedstock share claim. [3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity is treated as ground truth, and the norskeutslipp permit lists Hafsil AS with org. no. 887 760 292, supporting the same entity. The permit shows NACE 24.102 (a more specific ferroalloy subclass) versus the pre-filled 24.100, which is not treated as a contradiction.[2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Hafsil publicly states that it produces its ferro-silicon spheres by converting recycled steel and iron feedstocks, and its process overview explicitly shows scrap iron entering the furnace, indicating a core inbound metal-scrap SRM input (A3).[3] The permit confirms industrial-scale production of water-atomised Ferro Silicium powder (up to 10,000 t/year output), but does not disclose inbound recycled-feedstock quantities.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled steel and iron scrap feedstocks
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as furnace feedstocks in Hafsil's process for producing water-atomised 15% ferrosilicon spheres/powder.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The website describes the product as made by converting recycled steel and iron feedstocks and shows scrap iron entering the furnace, which indicates SRM is part of the core production route.[3] The permit confirms the same product/process is operated at industrial scale (up to 10,000 t/year output); this strengthens a T3 classification, but the scale-to-input linkage is an inference because input tonnage is not disclosed.[2]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct inbound tonnage or recycled-share percentage for steel/iron feedstocks was found in the reviewed permit or website pages. The permit provides product output capacity (up to 10,000 t/year), not measured SRM input mass.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Website text confirms recycled steel and iron feedstocks are used, but it does not specify whether all feedstock is recycled, the exact feedstock mix, or annual purchased/received SRM volumes.[3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: The reviewed permit text confirms product type and output capacity, but no explicit raw-material input list or inbound SRM quantity was identified in the accessed sections.[2]
Evidence for inbound SRM use comes from company website process/marketing text; independent public quantification of actual annual recycled metal input volumes was not found in this review.[3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The entity was resolved as the Norwegian company Hafslund Celsio AS using matching company name and org number on Proff, cross-checked against the Miljødirektoratet permit record for Klemetsrud [1][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Hafslund Celsio uses large-scale inbound residual waste as a core feedstock in waste-to-energy operations (377,634 t burned in 2024), with permit framework up to 410,000 t/year at Klemetsrud [2][4].

srm_inputs.label: Residual waste feedstock for waste-to-energy incineration
srm_inputs.used_for: The company incinerates non-reusable/non-recyclable waste and uses the recovered heat for district heating and electricity production [2][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is core to operations: reported burned waste is 377,634 t in 2024, and permit conditions define large annual intake capacity and waste categories [2][4].

main_quantity.context: Reported as total burned waste amount across Klemetsrud and Haraldrud for 2024 [2].

other_quantities.context: Klemetsrud permit states maximum annual total waste intake [4].
Klemetsrud permit specifies annual limit for ordinary waste including household/commercial residual waste [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct annual inbound mass is disclosed for 2024 (377,634 t burned waste). Permit limits provide additional site-level envelope for Klemetsrud [2][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The public key-figures page aggregates burned waste and does not disclose detailed composition shares (e.g., recyclable vs non-recyclable fractions within received streams) [2].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-wide audited SRM composition split (by waste subtype) was found in accessible public sources used here [2][4].
Support fuels are disclosed, but the sources used do not prove these are secondary raw materials, so they were excluded from SRM input quantification [2][4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity data was treated as ground truth as instructed, and the reviewed Hallingplast website pages are consistent with the company name Hallingplast AS; no discrepancy was observed [1][2][3][4][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Hallingplast provides concrete evidence of inbound SRM use in plastics through in-house reuse of internal production scrap, a scaled return/recycling loop for external end-of-life plastic with stated 10,000 t/year startup capacity, and ISCC PLUS biosircular waste-derived raw materials supplied via mass balance for product offerings [1][2][3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Internally recycled PE/PP production scrap
srm_inputs.used_for: Hallingplast states that plastic waste from production start-up and rejected pipes is chopped/granulated in its own plant and reused in production, and that this recycled material is used in other products [1][2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes an established in-house recycling setup and states 100% of its own discarded plastic material is recycled, indicating a systematic and meaningful SRM input stream even though total tonnage is not disclosed [1][2].

share.context: The 100% figure refers to Hallingplast's own discarded/internal plastic material stream being recycled and reused, not total company polymer input [1][2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct mass quantity for internally recycled scrap input was found in the reviewed public pages; the available quantification is a 100% recycling statement for Hallingplast's own discarded material [1][2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The sources do not disclose what share of total annual raw-material consumption this internal recycled stream represents, and one page indicates the recycled material is used in other products rather than all long-life pipe applications [2].

srm_inputs.label: Returned end-of-life plastic recyclate (external streams)
srm_inputs.used_for: Hallingplast describes damaged/irreparable external plastic being ground and granulated at a new Fr ya facility before being returned to Hallingplast, and states it expects to use all recycled plastic material itself [4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: A dedicated circular-plastic factory/recycling setup is described with startup capacity of 10,000 tonnes of recycled plastic per year and expected internal use of all recovered material, indicating meaningful scale; however, the figure is stated capacity/expectation rather than confirmed realized annual consumption [4].

main_quantity.context: The 10,000 t value is presented as startup annual production capacity for recycled plastic and is used here as a proxy for SRM input scale, not verified actual throughput [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The reviewed news page provides startup capacity (10,000 t/year) and expected internal use, but not audited actual intake or annual consumption volumes after startup [4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The key scale evidence comes from a company news article dated 29 October 2024 describing commissioning/startup context; the reviewed sources do not disclose realized 2025 or 2026 throughput [4].

srm_inputs.label: Bio-circular waste-derived polymer feedstock via ISCC PLUS mass balance
srm_inputs.used_for: Hallingplast states its raw-material suppliers deliver ISCC PLUS-certified biosircular raw materials to Hallingplast and that it supplies pipes classified with biosircular raw materials under a mass-balance approach [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company provides concrete statements on inbound biosircular raw-material supply and product offering options, but no purchased quantity, annual tonnage, or company-wide feedstock share is disclosed [1][3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: The company discloses product offer options with 25%, 50%, 75%, or 100% non-fossil raw-material content under mass balance, but not Hallingplast's actual annual intake volume of waste-derived biosircular feedstock [1][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The mass-balance page states Hallingplast cannot guarantee the physical pipe purchased is fossil-free, so the evidence confirms certified feedstock accounting and supplier delivery rather than physical-product content in each pipe [3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No reviewed source reports realized post-startup tonnage of external recycled plastic actually received and used by Hallingplast after the 2024 startup-capacity announcement [4].
The 100% recycling statements apply to Hallingplast's own discarded material stream, not to total company raw-material input across all products [1][2].
ISCC PLUS biosircular feedstock is described as waste-derived and supplied to Hallingplast, but no procurement volume or company-wide usage share is disclosed [1][3].

Hallingplast also reports use of recovered heat from a local waste-incineration plant for factory heating, but this was excluded because the provided SRM taxonomy does not include recovered district heat as a category [1].

employees.notes: Pre-filled employee count (46) was retained; a Proff snippet captured in project records aligns with the same headcount, but no year is stated in the snippet [2].

revenue.notes: Pre-filled revenue was retained; a Proff snippet captured in project records shows driftsinntekter 2024 of 126 717 tkr (126,717,000 NOK) [2].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity data was used as instructed. The Haplast website footer shows "Haplast AS," and no discrepancy was identified against the provided Proff reference/org number in the task input [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Haplast explicitly states that it buys recycled plastic material and uses it to produce wound profile pipes and blanks when standards allow, which is direct evidence of inbound SRM use in plastic production (A4) [1]. No quantitative amount or share is disclosed on the reviewed page [1].

srm_inputs.label: Purchased recycled plastic material
srm_inputs.used_for: Purchased recycled plastic material is used to produce wound profile pipes and blanks when standards permit [1].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company confirms actual use of recycled plastic input, but the wording is conditional (only when standards allow) and no volume/share is reported, so the evidence supports minor/limited documented use rather than clearly meaningful or core use [1].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No annual tonnage, purchased mass, or percentage share of recycled plastic input is disclosed on the reviewed sustainability page [1].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The page does not specify polymer grades, product-level coverage, or the proportion of total feedstock represented by purchased recycled plastic. It also mentions internal mechanical recycling of production waste without quantifying reuse as input [1].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No direct quantity or share of purchased recycled plastic input was found, which prevents aggregation of SRM volume for this company [1].
The evidence is a single qualitative website statement and does not identify material specifications or the extent of use across Haplast's product portfolio [1].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity fields were used as instructed and no discrepancy was found during SRM-focused research; reviewed AKVA group disclosures are consistent with Helgeland Plast in Mo i Rana [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Helgeland Plast shows clear SRM input use in production: the annual report states about 60% of its generated scrap (289 tons) was reintegrated into pipe production in 2024, and 29 tons of climate-neutral bio-oil-based raw material were used for a few working boats; the group also reports testing a fully recycled HDPE pen sourced from discarded pens [2].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled in-house plastic scrap reintegrated into pipe production
material_examples: HDPE scrap from boat, pipe and pen manufacturing
srm_inputs.used_for: Helgeland Plast reintegrates generated plastic scrap from boat, pipe and pen manufacturing into pipe production at its Mo i Rana operation [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The annual report discloses a recurring 2024 quantity (289 tons) and states this equals about 60% of scrap generated at Helgeland Plast, indicating meaningful use as a production input for pipes [2].

main_quantity.context: Annual report 2024 states that about 60% of scrap generated at Helgeland Plast, equal to 289 tons, was reintegrated into pipe production in 2024 [2].

share.context: Reported percentage is the share of generated scrap reintegrated, not the share of total raw-material input [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: This is directly quantified secondary plastic input to pipe production, but it is an internal scrap loop rather than externally purchased recycled polymer [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The report does not disclose the total pipe resin input denominator, so the recycled-input share of pipe production cannot be calculated [2].

srm_inputs.label: Climate-neutral HDPE based on bio-oil / waste-residual feedstocks
material_examples: Waste- and residual-stream-derived polyolefin feedstock (e.g., used cooking oil, forest waste)
srm_inputs.used_for: AKVA group reports use of climate-neutral HDPE to produce boats at Helgeland Plast, and describes ISCC PLUS-certified raw materials based on bio-based/recycled sources (including used cooking oil and forest waste) for workboats and fish pens [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The report quantifies 29 tons in 2024 used for only 'a few working boats', which confirms actual use but at limited scale; this entry is mapped to A10 because the disclosed input is bio-oil/waste-residual-feedstock-based material [2].

main_quantity.context: Group resource-inflow disclosure reports 29 tons of climate-neutral bio-oil-based raw material used in 2024 for a few working boats; methodology text links boat production use to Helgeland Plast [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct tonnage is disclosed (29 tons in 2024), but the report does not split this amount by exact model mix or clarify any fish-pen share versus boat share [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The annual report describes the material as climate-neutral HDPE and also as bio-based/recycled feedstock-derived (waste/residual streams), but does not quantify the recycled fraction versus bio-based fraction [2].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled HDPE from discarded fish pens (pen production/testing)
material_examples: Recycled HDPE sourced from discarded pens
srm_inputs.used_for: AKVA group reports testing a fully recycled pen made from HDPE sourced from discarded pens, and identifies Helgeland Plast in Mo i Rana as the group's pen, pipe and boat production facility [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence shows successful 2024 testing/sea-trial performance for a first fully recycled pen, but no recurring annual tonnage or established commercial production volume for Helgeland Plast is disclosed [2].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No Helgeland-Plast-specific tonnage or percentage for recycled HDPE input to pen production is disclosed in the reviewed public sources [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The annual report presents a proven test case and innovation progress, but not a quantified steady-state recycled-input flow for pen production at Helgeland Plast [2].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Public disclosures reviewed do not provide a Helgeland-Plast-only breakdown of recycled or bio-based input tonnage by product line beyond the 289-ton scrap reintegration and 29-ton climate-neutral boat-material figures [2].
The 60% figure for scrap reintegration refers to generated scrap at Helgeland Plast, not to total material inflow or total production output [2].
The annual report confirms use/testing of recycled and climate-neutral materials, but does not disclose product-level recycled-content percentages for Helgeland Plast boats, pipes, or pens [2].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity was resolved as HYDRO ALUMINIUM AS (org.nr. 917 537 534) via Proff official registry fields.[1] A DNV verification statement was commissioned by Hydro Aluminium AS and lists Hydro Aluminium AS Norwegian smelter sites, supporting that this is the relevant operating entity for assessed aluminium production inputs.[2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence shows inbound recycled aluminium scrap is used as an input in Hydro Aluminium AS-related casthouse/casting charge mixes (post-consumer and pre-consumer scrap).[2] Hydro also states used aluminium is taken back, remelted, and blended into new aluminium production, with a stated Høyanger recycling capability of about 33,000 t/year distributed to multiple Norwegian plants.[3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminium scrap input
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as feed in casthouse/casting charge mixes and remelt-blend routes for new aluminium products in Norwegian plants linked to Hydro Aluminium AS.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The input is clearly operational (not merely conceptual): verification documentation includes post- and pre-consumer scrap in casting charge material accounting, and Hydro describes industrial remelt/blending plus substantial annual recycling capacity (33,000 t/year at Høyanger facility feeding several plants).[2][3]

main_quantity.context: Hydro states Høyanger Resirkulering can recycle about 33,000 tonnes of used aluminium per year.[3]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The 33,000 t figure is stated as expected site recycling capability ("vil kunne") rather than audited realized annual intake for Hydro Aluminium AS consolidated operations.[3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Public evidence confirms scrap input use and site-level capability, but does not provide a verified realized annual SRM input total specifically at Hydro Aluminium AS legal-entity aggregate level.[2][3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No public Hydro Aluminium AS legal-entity report was found with realized annual inbound SRM tonnage split by site/material for the same reporting year.[2][3]
Available statements mix legal-entity and business-line/product documentation, so allocation of all recycled input volumes strictly to Hydro Aluminium AS remains partially inferred.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Prefilled identity is retained. However, Hydro's 2018 annual report identifies Hydro Extruded Solutions AS as a local holding company and lists Hydro Extrusion Norway AS separately as extrusion production, so SRM evidence at Magnor is treated as related-entity evidence rather than direct evidence for this legal entity [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: No direct evidence was found that HYDRO EXTRUDED SOLUTIONS AS itself uses secondary raw materials as inbound inputs. Hydro sources do show recycled-aluminium input use in related Norwegian extrusion operations (Hydro Extrusion Norway at Magnor), including Hydro CIRCAL supplied from Magnor and described as containing at least 75% post-consumer recycled aluminium [2][3][4].
gaps_and_uncertainties: Hydro's annual report classifies Hydro Extruded Solutions AS as a local holding company and Hydro Extrusion Norway AS as a separate extrusion production company, which limits direct attribution of Magnor plant SRM use to org. no. 899286952 [2].
Hydro Magnor/Søve sources confirm Hydro CIRCAL availability and recycled-content characteristics, but they do not disclose actual purchased/used SRM volumes for Hydro Extruded Solutions AS [3][4].
No entity-specific SRM procurement disclosure, sustainability report, or permit documentation for org. no. 899286952 was identified in the sources used here [2][3][4].

employees.notes: Pre-filled employee count (102) was used as ground truth for this run [1]. A Hydro Magnor site page shows 87 employees for the plant, likely reflecting a different snapshot/site-level figure [3].

revenue.notes: Revenue was taken from the pre-filled company metadata and not independently re-verified in this run [1].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The pre-filled legal entity and org number align with the Magnor permit naming ('Hydro Extrusion Norway AS, avd. Magnor') and Hydro's Magnor plant page; no identity discrepancy was found [2][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Hydro Magnor is an aluminum extrusion/surface-treatment site, and Hydro states Magnor added Hydro CIRCAL to its customer offering. Hydro CIRCAL is a recycled post-consumer scrap-based aluminum product available as extrusion ingot, indicating inbound recycled aluminum input use at Magnor, but no site-specific SRM volume/share was found [2][3][4][5][6].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminum (post-consumer scrap-based extrusion ingot/billet)
material_examples: recycled post-consumer aluminum scrap-based extrusion ingot
srm_inputs.used_for: Magnor extrudes and finishes aluminum components/profiles, and Hydro reports that Magnor added Hydro CIRCAL to its offering. Hydro CIRCAL is a recycled aluminum product available as extrusion ingot, which indicates recycled aluminum metal input for extrusion production [2][3][4][5][6].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence supports that Hydro CIRCAL (recycled aluminum) is part of Magnor's offering and that Magnor processes aluminum billets/ingots in extrusion. However, the reviewed sources do not quantify Magnor's actual consumption or regular share of recycled input, so use is evidenced but unquantified [3][4][5][6].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct Magnor-specific tonnage or percentage for Hydro CIRCAL/recycled aluminum input was identified. The 7,500-tonne figure on the Hydro Magnor page describes overall site production, not SRM input volume [3][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The Magnor article confirms Hydro CIRCAL was added to the customer offering, but it does not state how much was sold/processed at Magnor or the average recycled-content mix across production orders [4][5][6].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No site-level annual quantity or share of recycled aluminum input (e.g., Hydro CIRCAL tonnage) was found in the reviewed Hydro pages or the permit [2][3][4].
The reviewed permit confirms the Magnor aluminum profile activity but does not specify recycled feedstock input requirements, limits, or actual usage [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed Hydro's site page and the current permit for Hydro Vigelands Brug. Publicly available evidence describes high-purity aluminium refining, hydropower supply, and some diesel use for start-up, but no explicit inbound recycled/recovered/waste-derived material or energy input is documented for this site.[2][3]
gaps_and_uncertainties: The Hydro location page describes products, output and power supply, but does not disclose raw-material feedstock composition or recycled-content input for the Vennesla site.[3]

The permit describes the production process and emissions obligations, and contains a generic sector category wording mentioning "sekundærråstoffer", but it does not state that Hydro Vigelands Brug actually uses secondary raw materials as inbound inputs.[2]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Research sources identify the operating site as INEOS Tyssedal and the permit holder as "Ineos Tyssedal AS, avdeling titanslagg" with a branch org number, while the pre-filled parent company identity (934505557) is retained per task instructions [1][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Based on the reviewed sources, no evidence was found that INEOS Tyssedal currently uses recycled, recovered, reused, or waste-derived materials/fuels as inbound production inputs. The sources describe an ilmenite smelter process and indicate primary inputs such as ilmenite and coal, while permit references to "avrakeslagg" and "returmasse" appear under waste handling and temporary storage sections rather than inbound feedstock use [1][2][3].
gaps_and_uncertainties: Publicly available pages reviewed here do not disclose whether any minor internal recycle loops (e.g., reintroduced fines/returns/rework) are used in the process, so undisclosed low-volume SRM use cannot be fully excluded [1][2][3].
No quantified inbound recycled-material or waste-derived fuel usage was disclosed in the reviewed company pages, third-party process description, or the examined pollution permit text [1][2][3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity fields were retained as instructed. The company website uses the brand name "Industriplast AS," which appears to be a branding/common-name variant rather than a different entity [1].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Company website and product-catalog sources show operational use of recycled plastic as an inbound raw material, including an on-site plastic recycling setup with reuse in new products, recycled PE in pipe/hose materials, and a cable-cover product claim of over 99% recycled material [1][2][3]. No company-wide annual recycled-input tonnage or total recycled-input share was found in reviewed sources [1][2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed plastic polymers (recycled plastic / recycled PE)
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as raw material/input in plastic production, including reuse in new products, pipe and hose production with recycled PE, and other products developed in recycled material [1][2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates recurring operational use of recycled plastic inputs (not only an ambition): the company states on-site plastic recycling and reuse in new products, describes recycled plastic as raw material, and product/catalog content references recycled PE and recycled-material products [1][2]. A stronger tier is not justified because company-wide input volumes/shares are not disclosed [1][2][3].

share.context: A cable-protection product catalog states dekkplater are produced with "over 99%" recycled material; 99% is stored as a conservative minimum product-level share [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct company-level annual mass/volume of recycled plastic inputs was identified in the reviewed website or catalogs. Available quantification is limited to a product-level recycled-content share claim for dekkplater [1][2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The sources do not quantify total recycled-plastic input across all production, and they do not separate internally recycled material (on-site recycling) from externally purchased recyclate [1][2].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-wide annual tonnage (or other direct quantity) of recycled plastic input was found in reviewed sources [1][2][3].
No company-wide percentage share of recycled input in total production/feedstock was found; only a product-specific >99% claim for dekkplater was identified [3].
The source set reviewed does not disclose sourcing split or supplier details for recycled plastic inputs (internal regrind vs external recyclate) [1][2].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity for ISOLA AS is consistent with the reviewed Eidanger permit (same company name and org. number). One pre-matched permit is issued to Hunton Fiber AS (Isolasjonsfabrikken) and was excluded from ISOLA AS SRM attribution [1][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Confirmed inbound SRM evidence was found for recycled HDPE used in an Isola product (Platon DE25 Xtra). The reviewed Eidanger permit documents site production context but does not specify recycled input streams or quantities, and no company-wide SRM tonnage/share was found in the reviewed sources [2][1]. A separate pre-matched permit belongs to Hunton Fiber AS and was not attributed to ISOLA AS [3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled HDPE
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as material in the Platon DE25 Xtra board, which is described for drainage/storage applications in green roofs [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Isola explicitly states that Platon DE25 Xtra is made of recycled HDPE, but the evidence is product-specific and does not provide company-wide recycled polymer input volume, share, or broader coverage across product lines [2].

main_quantity.context: The product page lists the material as recycled HDPE and gives unit weight as 2.808 kg; this is used as a product-level proxy only, not annual company input volume [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No annual quantity of recycled HDPE consumed/purchased by ISOLA AS was disclosed in the reviewed sources. Only product-level material identity and unit weight were available [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The reviewed page does not state recycled-content percentage (if not fully recycled HDPE) or production volume for this product, so company-level SRM tonnage cannot be estimated reliably [2].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The reviewed Eidanger permit describes emissions and production of asphalt-based products, but it does not enumerate recycled/raw-material input streams [1].
No annual or site-level purchased/used quantities of recycled polymer inputs were found in the reviewed Isola source(s) [2].
One pre-matched norskeutslipp permit is for Hunton Fiber AS Isolasjonsfabrikken (different legal entity) and was excluded from ISOLA AS conclusions [3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Norwegian legal entity selected is JØTUL AS (AS), org. no. 989 519 247, on Proff.[1] Norskeutslipp permit documents also identify Jøtul’s Fredrikstad operation and show facility-level org. no. 974284847 linked to the same company context.[4][5]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Jøtul has clear evidence of inbound SRM use: recycled scrap iron is used as feedstock for cast iron manufacturing, and cast iron is central to its products.[2][3] This indicates SRM is core rather than pilot use.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled scrap iron
material_examples: Recycled scrap iron from local scrap dealers
Recycled iron feed for cast iron production
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as inbound feedstock to produce cast iron for fireplaces/stoves at the foundry and manufacturing operations.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The annual report states all cast iron production uses recycled iron, and cast-iron fireplaces are core products; this supports significant/core SRM dependence.[2] Additional company text confirms daily scrap-iron deliveries.[3]

share.context: The report states all cast iron production is with recycled iron; treated as a 100% recycled feedstock share for cast-iron production, not total company mass input.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual tonnage of recycled scrap iron input was found in the reviewed public sources.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The strongest quantified statement is a qualitative 100% share for cast-iron production; absolute mass/energy input volumes are not disclosed publicly in reviewed sources.[2][3] Permit documents confirm cast-iron production context but do not provide SRM input tonnage.[4]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-level disclosed tonnage (t/year) for recycled scrap iron input was identified in reviewed annual report, website pages, or permit text.[2][3][4]
Permit text confirms production and environmental framework, but not detailed inbound SRM mass-balance data.[4]
