company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity was treated as ground truth per instructions; the VPI website states VPI is part of Kingspan Water & Energy, consistent with the provided company name [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed VPI/Kingspan pages describe production in GRP/PE/PVC and a product EPD/news item documenting recycled MDPE in EcoLine II PE separators (up to 100% for one variant), but no company-wide SRM input volumes are disclosed [3][5][6].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled MDPE in EcoLine II PE separators
material_examples: EcoLine II PE-based oil/sludge separator bodies
srm_inputs.used_for: The company website's EPD/news page states EcoLine II PE-based separators use recycled MDPE, indicating recycled polymer input in products offered under the company's portfolio [5][6].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence explicitly confirms recycled polymer content for a specific product family, but only product-level composition shares are disclosed and there is no company/site-level intake volume or share of total production [5][6].

share.context: EPD Table 6 reports 100% recycled-material content in the main product for the 600 l EcoLine II variant [6].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual mass/volume of recycled MDPE input is disclosed. The EPD provides product-level recycled-content shares (100% for 600 l and 40% for 2000 l variants) [6].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The EPD is product-specific and does not disclose how much of this product line the Norwegian entity sells or manufactures at the Andebu site [2][5][6].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed production and quality/environment pages describe materials and certifications but do not publish company-level raw material intake or recycled-input totals [3][4].
The identified recycled-content evidence is limited to an EcoLine II EPD/product communication and may not represent the full product portfolio or the Andebu production mix [5][6].
No public annual sustainability/ESG report was identified in the reviewed company sources that quantifies SRM input volumes for the Norwegian legal entity [2][4][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed company website pages confirm aluminum/glass production and installation activities, but the reviewed sources do not provide explicit evidence of recycled, recovered, reused, or waste-derived materials used as inbound inputs [1][2][3][4][5].

No quantified inbound SRM volumes or shares were found in the reviewed sources; this is a no-evidence finding (T0), not proof that SRM inputs are absent [1][2][3][4][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Metallco Aluminium AS describes its alloy production as based on recycled aluminium scrap inputs, indicating SRM as a core feedstock for operations.[2] No audited inbound SRM mass figure was found in the reviewed public sources.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminium scrap feedstock
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as the main feedstock for melting/remelting and producing secondary aluminium foundry alloys.[2]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company states all alloys are produced from recycled aluminium and all production is based on melting used aluminium scrap, which indicates core dependence on SRM input.[2]

share.context: The company states that all alloys are produced from recycled aluminium and that all production is based on melting used aluminium scrap.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Public company text reports production volumes (about 15,000 tonnes alloys and up to 5,000 tonnes toll remelting), which indicates industrial scale but not a direct measured inbound SRM tonnage disclosure.[2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: No explicit annual inbound scrap mass balance (actual received/purchased SRM) was identified in the reviewed pages and permit extract.[2][3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No source found with audited annual inbound aluminium scrap quantity for this legal entity/facility.[2][3]
Permit extract confirms facility classification but does not provide a clear annual actual SRM input-use figure in the extracted text.[3][4]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Used the pre-filled identity fields as ground truth. No material discrepancy found; Nefab's locations page lists "Nefab Packaging Norway A/S" at the Sande address, which matches the provided company/address with only A/S vs AS styling difference [1][6].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: There is evidence on Nefab's Norwegian-language product pages that some packaging solutions use recycled paper fibers and recycled plastics as inbound material content (e.g., FiberFlute and recycled-content plastic solutions). However, the reviewed sources do not provide Norway-company-specific volumes or shares for NEFAB PACKAGING NORWAY AS [1][2][3][4][5].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled paper and cardboard fibers
srm_inputs.used_for: Used in Nefab's FiberFlute fiber-based inner packaging/cushioning solution presented on the Norwegian-language site; the page states the product is made from recycled paper [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence confirms recycled paper content in a Nefab packaging solution marketed on the Norwegian site, but no company-level data confirms how much NEFAB PACKAGING NORWAY AS purchases or uses in Norway [1][2].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct quantity (mass/volume) or share for recycled paper input use by NEFAB PACKAGING NORWAY AS was disclosed in the reviewed sources [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The evidence is product-page level and does not explicitly state actual purchased/consumed recycled paper volumes at the Norwegian legal entity or sites [1][2].

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed plastics (recycled plastic content, incl. recycled HDPE)
srm_inputs.used_for: Used in Nefab plastic packaging solutions described on the Norwegian-language site, including Reflex cushioning (thermoformed HDPE with high recycled content) and plastic containers/totes with recycled plastic content [3][4][5].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Multiple Norwegian-language Nefab product/material pages describe recycled plastic content, indicating SRM plastic inputs in offered solutions, but no Norway-entity-specific usage volumes or shares are disclosed [1][3][4][5].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct quantity or share of recycled plastic input used by NEFAB PACKAGING NORWAY AS in Norway was found in the reviewed sources [3][4][5].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Statements include portfolio/product claims (including "up to" recycled-content wording) and may not represent actual realized input mixes at the Norwegian company sites [1][3][4][5].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No Norway-specific annual report, sustainability report section, or permit document with quantified inbound SRM use for NEFAB PACKAGING NORWAY AS was identified in the reviewed sources used here [1][2][3][4][5].

The strongest evidence found is product/solution-level recycled-content claims on Nefab's Norwegian-language webpages, which supports probable SRM input use but not company-level quantities for the Norwegian legal entity [1][2][3][4][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed public NFM Group pages confirm NFM Technology AS performs ballistic-composite R&D/production using FREC-2 technology, but they do not disclose recycled/recovered/waste-derived inbound material, feedstock, or energy inputs. The sustainability page mentions waste being recycled/recovered, which is an outflow metric and not evidence of inbound SRM use [3][4].
gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed NFM Group pages describe business activities and composite production, but do not disclose polymer/fiber input composition, recycled-content shares, or recovered feedstock use for NFM Technology AS [3].
The sustainability page is group-level and reports environmental performance (including waste recycling/recovery) without identifying inbound SRM inputs for NFM Technology AS [4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed sources indicate a group-level 2024 initiative to establish plastic recycling for reuse in own production, but they do not quantify or clearly attribute actual SRM input use to NOFI Tromsø AS specifically [3][2].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastic for reuse in own production (group initiative)
srm_inputs.used_for: NOFI's 2024 annual report states work to establish the possibility of recycling plastic for reuse in the group's own production, indicating intended use of recycled plastic as a production input [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The evidence is initiative-stage (establishing possibility) and does not confirm routine consumption, scale, or site-specific implementation at NOFI Tromsø AS, so this is assessed as minor/pilot evidence [3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct quantity, share, or time-based consumption figure for recycled plastic input is disclosed in the reviewed annual report or sustainability webpage [3][2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The recycling statement is reported at NOFI group level and does not specify whether NOFI Tromsø AS itself used recycled plastic inputs in 2024 or only participated in preparatory work [3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The reviewed sustainability webpage mentions environmental considerations in raw-material and procurement choices, but no explicit SRM input types or percentages are disclosed there [2].
The annual report describes establishing plastic recycling for reuse in own production, but it does not provide company-level implementation details or volumes for NOFI Tromsø AS [3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity fields were used as instructed; the Lycro homepage footer confirms the legal name NOPLA AS, indicating Lycro is the brand/site for NOPLA AS. [1][2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: NOPLA (Lycro) explicitly states it uses significant amounts of recycled plastic in production and markets a Recreated product series made from recycled plastic, with product pages claiming 70% to 100% recycled content. [3][4][5][6][7]

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed plastic polymers (recycled PP and recycled HDPE)
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as inbound plastic raw material in Lycro's "Recreated" product line, including products such as FIXA, OMNIA and DURA. [4][5][6][7]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company states it uses significant amounts of recycled plastic in production and provides multiple product pages with high recycled-content claims (70%-100%), which supports meaningful ongoing use rather than a pilot. [3][4][5][6][7]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No company-level annual mass/volume of recycled plastic input was found. Available quantification is limited to product/portfolio content claims (e.g., portfolio up to 70%, DURA 70%, OMNIA 90-95%, FIXA 100% recycled PP). [3][5][6][7]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The reviewed pages do not disclose total inbound recycled-polymer procurement volumes, the share across all production, or the period for the percentage claims. Product-level percentages may not represent company-wide input mix. [3][4][5][6][7]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-level tonnage (t/kg) of recycled plastic inputs was disclosed on the reviewed website pages, so aggregation-grade volume data is unavailable. [3][4][5][6][7]
The sustainability page says the portfolio contains up to 70% recycled material, while some product pages claim 90-100%; the scope and timing of these claims are not clarified. [3][5][6][7]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity was treated as ground truth per instruction; reviewed permit and company website naming/activity are consistent with Norfolier GreenTec AS and its Folldal plastic-film recycling operation [1][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Norfolier GreenTec shows clear inbound SRM use centered on recycled plastic film feedstock (industrial/agricultural polyethylene film). The Folldal permit covers receiving, washing and recycling this plastic film, and company pages describe accepting LDPE film and using recycled plastic from Folldal in refuse sacks and recyclate products [1][2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled PE plastic film waste (industrial and agricultural)
srm_inputs.used_for: At the Folldal facility, agricultural/industrial polyethylene film is received, washed and recycled into PE pellets/agglomerate; company pages also link recycled plastic from Folldal to the company’s refuse sacks and recyclate products [1][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: T3 is assigned because recycled PE film waste is a core input to the permitted Folldal recycling operation (with a large annual receiving limit) and the company describes major product lines based on recycled plastic from this operation [1][3].

main_quantity.context: Permit clause 1.1 states the Folldal plant may receive up to 26,000 tonnes/year of agricultural/industrial plastic film (polyethylene film); this is a permit limit, not confirmed actual intake [1].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No recent public actual annual intake volume was found in the reviewed sources. The permit provides a Folldal site receiving limit (26,000 t/year), and the permit background notes intake was expected to exceed 20,000 t/year at the time of the application [1].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Quantification is permit-based and site-specific (Folldal). Reviewed company pages confirm the material type and downstream use, but do not publish current company-wide inbound SRM tonnage or mix by source type [1][2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No reviewed source published recent actual annual inbound tonnage of recycled plastic film; the strongest quantitative figure is the permit receiving limit for the Folldal site [1].

Company pages confirm LDPE film collection from industry/agriculture and product use of recycled plastic, but they do not disclose a current split between industrial vs agricultural input volumes or company-wide totals [2][3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The selected entity is the Norwegian legal company NORSK GJENVINNING AS (AS), org. no. 937270062, on Proff; the company website footer also names Norsk Gjenvinning AS [1][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Norsk Gjenvinning AS shows meaningful inbound SRM use through large-scale intake and processing of waste-derived material streams, including plastics handled by NG Downstream and gypsum waste used to produce gypsum powder for further material recycling [4][2]. Permits also indicate very large intake capacities at Oslo operations, but those streams are mixed and not fully classifiable into one SRM category from public summaries alone [3].

srm_inputs.label: Plastic waste feedstock
srm_inputs.used_for: Plastic waste is sorted, quality-checked, baled, and sent to recyclers that produce granulate for new products [4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company’s downstream division reports handling 25,000 tonnes of plastic annually, indicating meaningful operational scale for recycled plastic input handling [4].

main_quantity.context: Stated as annual plastic volume handled by NG Downstream, described as Norsk Gjenvinning’s market and trading division [4].

other_quantities.context: Listed as approximate annual sub-volume for agricultural film within handled plastic streams [4].
Listed as approximate annual sub-volume for clear film within handled plastic streams [4].
Listed as approximate annual sub-volume for colored film within handled plastic streams [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Publicly disclosed as handled annual volume; treated here as inbound received input to sorting/trading operations [4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The disclosed volume includes volumes from NG and external trading customers, so legal-entity-only attribution is not fully explicit [4].

srm_inputs.label: Gypsum waste (construction mineral stream)
srm_inputs.used_for: At Holmestrand, gypsum waste is received and processed (sorting and grinding) to produce gypsum powder for further material recycling by external actors [2].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Company-wide actual annual inbound SRM tonnage for Norsk Gjenvinning AS is not disclosed in the reviewed sources; available figures are site permits or division-level handling data [2][4].
A large Oslo permit volume is documented, but public summary text does not provide enough fraction detail to map all streams cleanly to one MECE SRM code each [3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Used the pre-filled company identity (Norsk Hydro ASA, org. no. 914778271) as instructed and focused research on SRM inputs; no discrepancy was identified during this run.[1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Hydro provides clear evidence of inbound secondary raw material use centered on recycled aluminium scrap (post-consumer and process scrap) in recycling/remelting operations and products, including post-consumer scrap purchased from third parties, 451,000 tonnes of post-consumer scrap recycled in 2024, and Hydro CIRCAL products with minimum 75% post-consumer scrap content.[2][3][4] Hydro also reports biomethane replacing part of natural gas use at the Sunndal primary plant (site-level energy input). Classification of biomethane as B3 is an inference from the term used.[3]

srm_inputs.label: Post-consumer aluminium scrap (PCS)
srm_inputs.used_for: Hydro states it uses post-consumer aluminium scrap purchased from third parties for recycling into extrusion ingot, and Hydro CIRCAL remelts scrap into products including extrusion ingot and foundry alloys.[2][4] Hydro also describes recycled aluminium being mixed with primary aluminium in Norwegian casthouses.[3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Hydro describes a large-scale recycling platform (34 plant facilities and about 2.5 million tonnes annual recycling capacity) and reports 451,000 tonnes of post-consumer scrap recycled in 2024, indicating core and significant use rather than pilot activity.[3]

main_quantity.context: Hydro’s aluminium recycling page reports 451,000 tonnes of post-consumer scrap recycled in 2024 across Hydro’s recycling operations.[3]

share.context: Hydro CIRCAL is described as offering a minimum 75% post-consumer scrap (PCS) content, verified by DNV.[4]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct 2024 company-level quantity is available for post-consumer scrap (451,000 t), but the reviewed pages do not split that figure by country, legal entity, or individual product line.[3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 451,000 t figure and recycling platform descriptions are presented on Hydro group webpages and appear to describe Hydro’s broader recycling operations, not an explicitly Norway-only or legal-entity-only total for Norsk Hydro ASA.[2][3][4]

srm_inputs.label: Process / pre-consumer aluminium scrap
srm_inputs.used_for: Hydro states it recycles process scrap from its own aluminium production and from other companies, and also describes recycled aluminium being mixed with primary aluminium in Norwegian casthouses.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Hydro explicitly confirms process-scrap recycling as an input stream and describes pre-consumer scrap recycling as a natural and necessary part of the aluminium value chain, but no separate annual process-scrap tonnage is disclosed in the reviewed sources.[2][3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No standalone mass or share figure for process/pre-consumer scrap input was found on the reviewed Hydro pages.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The reviewed sources discuss process scrap at company/group level and technology deployment, but do not allocate process-scrap input volumes to the Norsk Hydro ASA legal-entity boundary.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Biomethane (inferred biogas)
srm_inputs.used_for: Hydro reports biomethane use at the Sunndal primary plant as part of remelting/casthouse energy transition efforts, where remelting aluminium into new products is described as fuel-intensive.[3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Hydro reports replacing 70 percent of natural gas consumption with locally sourced biomethane at the Sunndal primary plant, which indicates meaningful site-level use, but no company-wide biomethane quantity is disclosed.[3]

share.context: Hydro states that the Sunndal primary plant has replaced 70 percent of natural gas consumption with locally sourced biomethane; the reviewed page does not specify the reporting period for this share.[3]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Only a replacement share is disclosed (70% of natural gas consumption at Sunndal); no biomethane quantity in energy or volume units is provided.[3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Classification as B3 (biogas) is inferred from Hydro’s use of the term “biomethane”; the reviewed page does not specify biomethane feedstock origin (waste-derived vs other biomass) or the exact measurement period.[3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: The reviewed Hydro webpages describe Hydro’s global/group recycling operations and products; they do not provide a Norway-only or legal-entity-only SRM input inventory for Norsk Hydro ASA.[2][3][4]
No separate annual tonnage for process/pre-consumer aluminium scrap inputs was found in the reviewed sources.[2][3]
Biomethane use is reported as a 70 percent replacement share at one site (Sunndal), but no absolute energy quantity, duration, or feedstock provenance is disclosed on the reviewed page.[3]
Employees and revenue values were taken from the pre-filled prompt metadata as instructed and were not independently re-verified during this SRM-focused run.[1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Company website pages show an operating foundry and explicit remelting/reuse of offcuts/chips into new parts, and a company article states it also accepts others' non-ferrous scrap (including bronze/brass/copper/lead) to make new products [1][2].

srm_inputs.label: Non-ferrous metal scrap and process returns for remelting
srm_inputs.used_for: Offcuts/chips and other scrap are remelted in the foundry and used to produce new bushings/parts and other new products [1][2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The use is clearly recurring (described on homepage and article), includes both internal rest material and externally received scrap, and is tied to remelting into new products; however, no verified inbound tonnage or feedstock share is disclosed [1][2].

share.context: The company states it recovers/recycles 95% of its material; this is recorded as a company-level recycling/reuse indicator, not a verified inbound SRM feedstock share [1][2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual mass/volume of scrap input is disclosed on the reviewed pages; the available quantification is a 95% recycling/recovery claim without stated unit or period [1][2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 95% figure may combine internal rest-material reuse and broader recycling flows, and the pages do not define the mass basis, reporting period, or exact share of inbound feedstock from SRM [1][2].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No permit, annual report, or technical datasheet with quantified SRM input tonnage is included in the evidence set used here; assessment relies on company website pages [1][2].
Employees and revenue values were retained from pre-filled metadata and not independently verified during this SRM-focused research pass [3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: No discrepancy was observed between the pre-filled company identity and the Oldroyd website name/address in Stathelle [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Oldroyd publicly states it uses recycled plastic and offers products made from recycled sea plastic, while external articles describe recycled plastic in tunnel membranes (10%) and 100% recycled sea plastic feedstock in spacer products [3][4][5].

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed plastic in tunnel membrane products
srm_inputs.used_for: A TU article describing Oldroyd’s tunnel membrane production says virgin material has been gradually replaced with recycled material in the inner layers of the membranes [4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The source describes actual use (not just a pilot) and gives a current stated level of 10% recycled plastic in tunnel membranes, but it does not provide company-wide totals [4].

share.context: A TU quote states they are allowed to use 10% recycled plastic in tunnel membranes at the time of publication [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual tonnage of recycled plastic input is disclosed for Oldroyd. The same TU article only provides a scenario estimate (>500 tons) if the share increased to 20% in a Rogfast-scale tunnel project [4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The available evidence is from a media/advertorial article and is product-specific; it does not disclose audited company-wide SRM input volumes or current realized tonnage [4].

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed sea-plastic feedstock for concrete spacer products
srm_inputs.used_for: Oldroyd markets concrete-construction products made from recycled sea plastic, and KraussMaffei describes spacer products for tunnel concrete reinforcement made from this feedstock [3][5].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates a production use case with 100% recycled sea-plastic feedstock for a defined product family, but there is no company-wide purchasing or annual consumption disclosure [3][5].

share.context: KraussMaffei states that raw material in the referenced products is 100% recycled sea plastic [5].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct SRM mass input is reported. KraussMaffei provides product-use indicators (300,000-400,000 spacers per tunnel; about 150 g each) rather than company-wide annual recycled-plastic tonnage [5].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 100% figure is clearly tied to the cited product(s), not necessarily all Oldroyd product lines, and no annual procurement volumes are disclosed [3][5].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Available evidence is product-level and does not disclose total annual SRM tonnage or the share of recycled inputs across all Oldroyd production [3][4][5].
For tunnel membranes, the TU article distinguishes current stated use (10%) from a higher feasible target (20%), so scale-up should not be treated as current input use [4].

srm_inputs.uncertainties: The wording is forward-looking ("lagt opp til"), and it is unclear how much material was actually used versus planned [3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No accessible source in this review provides company-level annual SRM input tonnage/share for PEAB ANLEGG AS [1][3].
Could not substantiate additional inbound SRM categories (e.g., recycled metals/plastics/energy SRM) with entity-specific quantified evidence [2][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Pipelife Norge has evidence of commercial recycled-plastic use (recycled PP in Divio cable protection products) and pilot/test use of recycled PVC and recycled PE in pipe applications, but no company-level annual SRM input volumes are disclosed [3][4][5].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled polypropylene (PP) for Divio cable protection products
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as material in Divio cable channel/cable protection products sold by Pipelife Norge; the catalog product page lists the material as recycled PP, and company news states Divio is made from recycled PP [3][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence shows a marketed product/SKU and a product launch article describing Divio as made from recycled PP, which supports commercial use beyond a lab-only pilot; however, no company-wide adoption rate or tonnage is disclosed [3][4].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: Reviewed catalog/news sources confirm recycled-PP use qualitatively, but they do not disclose annual purchased or consumed recycled-PP quantities for Pipelife Norge [3][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The evidence confirms recycled-PP material designation for at least the cited Divio product and product line messaging, but not the share of total company production represented by Divio [3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled PVC in pilot three-layer cable pipe production
srm_inputs.used_for: Used in pilot/test production of three-layer cable pipes in the pipe-recycling project; the article caption describes a cable pipe with a middle layer containing about 50% recycled PVC [5].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The source frames this as project-based pilot testing (2024 pilot program) and test production, with no evidence of routine large-scale commercial deployment or annual recycled-PVC input volumes [5].

share.context: The article image caption states a three-layer cable pipe with a middle layer of approximately 50% recycled PVC; this is a pilot product-layer example, not a company-wide average [5].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No company-specific recycled-PVC tonnage is disclosed. The article reports pilot outcomes and examples, but not Pipelife Norge's actual consumed mass of recycled PVC [5].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 50% figure applies to a cable pipe middle layer in a pilot example and cannot be generalized to all products or ongoing production without additional disclosures [5].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled polyethylene (PE) in pilot drain and mantle pipe tests
srm_inputs.used_for: Used in pilot tests on drain pipes and mantle pipes during the pipe-recycling project [5].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates successful testing of recycled PE in specific pipe applications within a pilot project, but no routine production volumes, purchase volumes, or product-level percentages are disclosed [5].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No quantitative recycled-PE input volume or share is disclosed for Pipelife Norge in the reviewed source [5].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The article confirms pilot testing only; it does not quantify recycled-PE usage or state whether the tested formulations were commercialized [5].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed evidence establishes SRM use at product/pilot level, but not annual company-level inbound SRM tonnage (PP/PVC/PE) [3][4][5].
The cited 11.2-ton figure is a project-wide pipe collection result, not a disclosed Pipelife Norge SRM input quantity [5].
Current assessment relies on Pipelife website/catalog/news pages rather than a company sustainability report or annual SRM input statement with quantified totals [3][4][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Plasto reports using recycled plastic/recycled polymer as inbound material inputs in multiple product applications (aquaculture components/gangways, Invisible Connections components, and Berry Alloc flooring lock components). The strongest quantified evidence is a 40% recycled-material share in AKVA Group components (2022), but no company-wide annual SRM tonnage is disclosed [1][2][3][5].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastics / recycled polymer inputs
material_examples: Recycled plastic from marine/aquaculture waste streams
srm_inputs.used_for: Plasto states it replaces virgin plastic with recycled plastic in several product applications, including aquaculture walkways/gangways, components for Invisible Connections, and a Berry Alloc flooring lock made from recycled polymer [1][2][3][5].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates meaningful commercial use rather than a one-off pilot: Plasto reports a 40% recycled-material share in AKVA Group components (2022), production of seven recycled-plastic components for Invisible Connections, and launch of a recycled-polymer flooring lock with Berry Alloc. However, the evidence does not show company-wide resin input shares or tonnage, so T3 is not justified [1][2][5].

share.context: Plasto's sustainability page states that 40% of material consumption in AKVA Group components was recycled material; this is a product/program-level share, not a company-wide input share [1].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct mass/volume of recycled plastic inputs is disclosed on the cited pages. Available quantification is limited to product/program-level shares (e.g., 40% for AKVA components and a 100% recycled-material gangway example) [1][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The cited pages do not provide annual company-wide SRM tonnage, polymer-type breakdowns, or the share of recycled resin across Plasto's total procurement. Some examples are customer/project specific, which limits aggregation precision [1][2][3][5].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Plasto's public pages identify several recycled-plastic use cases, but they do not disclose company-level annual quantities (kg/t) of recycled polymer purchased or consumed [1][2][3][5].
Published examples show product/customer implementations and project outputs, but they do not clearly quantify how much of Plasto's total resin input is secondary versus virgin material [1][2][3][5].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Using the pre-filled identity (POLY HAR AS, org. no. 868108932) as instructed. The website content is branded as Vartdal Plast / Vartdal Plastindustri AS, which appears to be the operating brand shown on company pages [5][6].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: The company website provides evidence of inbound SRM use in product raw materials: recycled EPS/plastic in marketed products (including an R-EPS product stated to be made from 100% mechanically recycled raw materials) and VARTDAL LOOP EPS raw material using alternative feedstocks including pyrolysis oil from chemically recycled consumer plastic and biogas from waste, with fossil naphtha replaced via mass-balance allocation [1][4]. The company also describes dedicated EPS collection/compression activities intended to increase recycled material use in its products [2][3][5].

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed plastics (recycled EPS / recycled plastic raw materials)
material_examples: Used EPS (expanded polystyrene) returned for recycling
Recycled plastic rawstock for LOOP products
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as recycled plastic/EPS input for product lines, including R-EPS insulation products and LOOP products; the company states its Liadal EPS recovery activity aims to increase recycled material use in its products and to return collected EPS as new raw material [1][2][3][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates commercial use (not only ambition): product pages state 100% recycled content / 100% mechanically recycled raw materials for specific products, and company pages describe dedicated EPS collection/compression infrastructure feeding circular product ambitions [2][3][4].

share.context: Product-level claim for STYROPOR R-EPS S150 states it is made from 100% mechanically recycled raw materials; this is a product-scope share, not a company-wide share [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No exact company-wide inbound recycled-plastic/EPS tonnage into production is publicly disclosed on the reviewed pages. The company states that 'several thousand tonnes' of used EPS get new life annually, but this is not a precise numeric SRM input value for manufacturing consumption [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The public pages mix recovery/logistics statements with product claims. They support inbound recycled-material use, but they do not quantify how much collected EPS is directly reintroduced into the company's own production versus broader recycling flows [1][2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Pyrolysis oil from chemically recycled consumer plastic (mass-balance feedstock)
material_examples: Pyrolysis oil from chemically recycled consumer plastic
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as an alternative raw-source feedstock in the early production stage of EPS raw material for the VARTDAL LOOP product series; the page states fossil raw material (naphtha) is replaced and allocated through a mass-balance principle [1].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes current use in a marketed product series (VARTDAL LOOP), with named feedstock type and explicit fossil replacement / mass-balance allocation. However, no volume or company-wide share is disclosed [1].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No mass, volume, or percentage share is disclosed for pyrolysis-oil-derived feedstock in EPS raw material on the reviewed public pages [1].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The page describes feedstock substitution at the beginning of the EPS raw-material production process and distribution via mass balance, so the exact physical allocation to this company's sites/products is not quantified [1].

srm_inputs.label: Biogas (waste-derived) used as EPS raw-material feedstock via mass balance
material_examples: Biogas from food, agricultural, and forestry waste
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as an alternative raw-source feedstock in EPS raw material for VARTDAL LOOP products; the company explicitly states VARTDAL BIOPOR insulation plates use EPS raw material that uses biogas as raw material [1].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company presents biogas-based EPS raw material as part of an active commercial product series and explicitly links it to named insulation products (VARTDAL BIOPOR). Scale is not quantified, but usage is described as current and productized [1].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No quantified biogas input amount or substitution percentage is disclosed on the reviewed public pages [1].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The description indicates biogas is used upstream in EPS raw-material production and allocated via mass balance; on-site energy use versus upstream feedstock contribution is not broken out [1].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No annual report, sustainability report, or public permit document with quantified SRM input volumes (e.g., tonnes of recycled polymer used in production) was identified in the reviewed sources [1][2][3][4][5].

The 'several thousand tonnes' statement refers to used EPS getting new life through the 100% VARTDAL PLAST collection/compression initiative, but it does not provide an exact numeric inbound production-input figure for this legal entity's manufacturing operations [3].

For VARTDAL LOOP feedstocks (pyrolysis oil and biogas), the website describes replacement of naphtha and mass-balance allocation, but it does not disclose feedstock shares by product, plant, or year [1].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Protan publicly states that post-industrial recycled PVC is already used in several roof membrane products and describes a PROcycle roof membrane using recycled input from internal surplus and upcycled used roofing membranes, with product-level recycled-content claims around 5% (including a 4.5-6.5% range) [2][3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed PVC (post-industrial and upcycled membrane-derived PVC)
srm_inputs.used_for: Protan states that post-industrial recycled PVC is used in several roof membrane products, and its PROcycle membrane line uses recycled PVC inputs in roofing membrane production [2][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence is direct and operational (not only ambition): Protan states recycled PVC is already used in several roof membrane products and provides product-level recycled-content claims for PROcycle membranes, but no company-wide tonnage or portfolio-wide share is disclosed [2][3][4].

share.context: Product-level recycled-content claims state minimum 5% recycled raw material / 5% recycled content for the referenced roof membrane, while another Protan page gives a 4.5-6.5% range; the exact accounting basis is not explicitly defined in the reviewed pages [3][4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual mass/volume of recycled PVC input (company, site, or business-unit level) was found in the reviewed public sources. Available quantification is limited to product-level recycled-content percentages for the PROcycle roof membrane (minimum 5%, and 4.5-6.5% range) [2][3][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The reviewed sources do not quantify how many total products or what share of total production uses recycled PVC beyond stating "several roof membrane products," and they do not define the exact basis behind the published percentage claims (e.g., product mass vs recipe share) [2][3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No accessible reviewed source in this run disclosed company-level or Lier-site annual tonnes of recycled PVC input, inbound take-back volume, or recycled-feedstock procurement volume [2][3][4].

The published 5% and 4.5-6.5% figures are product-level claims for recycled content in the PROcycle membrane and cannot be directly scaled to total Protan AS SRM input without additional data [2][3][4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity fields were used as instructed, and the Ragasco contact page is consistent with the legal name Ragasco AS and organization number 878 612 752; no discrepancy was found [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Ragasco has direct evidence of plastic SRM use: its sustainability page states internal recycling of liner waste, and the 2023 sustainability report describes recycling activities at Ragasco that reintroduce waste as raw materials and enable HDPE reuse in new casings and injection moulded casing parts [3][4]. No direct inbound tonnage or feedstock share is disclosed in the cited sources. The SirkPlast text supports ongoing exploration of recycled thermoplastics but does not by itself prove routine production volumes [3].

srm_inputs.label: Internally recycled plastic production scrap (HDPE/PP liner scrap)
srm_inputs.used_for: Ragasco states it internally recycles liner waste, and the 2023 sustainability report describes granulation/pelletizing of internal HDPE/PP production scrap that enables HDPE reuse in new casings and injection moulded casing parts [3][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates operational (not only pilot-language) recycling/reuse activity connected to production scrap at Ragasco, including reported recycling activities that reintroduce waste as raw materials and a KPI on reducing HDPE waste through on-site recycling efforts [4].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No aggregation-ready mass/volume/energy quantity for recycled plastic input was disclosed in the cited Ragasco website page or the cited 2023 sustainability report excerpts [3][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The cited report includes a route where granulated liner scrap is sent to former Ragasco sites for pelletizing, so the exact split between same-site reuse and reuse at related sites is not quantified; no total feedstock share is disclosed [4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No direct quantity (t/kg) or percentage share of recycled plastic in total input was found in the cited sources, so this SRM assessment is qualitative for aggregation purposes [3][4].
The SirkPlast statement confirms exploration of recycled thermoplastics, but it does not establish steady-state production use levels or volumes [3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity is consistent with accessed company/EPD sources: the company states a January 2024 rename from Hydal Aluminium Profiles to Raufoss Aluminium, and the EPD lists org. no. 912 445 313 for Raufoss Aluminium AS [3][5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Raufoss Aluminium uses recycled aluminium as an inbound core material input in its aluminium profile production. The company states its products contain a high percentage of recycled aluminium, and the average-profile EPD says the declared product reflects aluminium sources the company procures/uses and consists of about 40% recycled aluminium scrap; however, a separate low-carbon profile EPD is modeled as 100% primary aluminium, so recycled content varies by product grade [1][2][3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminium scrap in aluminium feedstock for profile production
srm_inputs.used_for: Raufoss Aluminium states its production is based on aluminium bolts, and the average-profile EPD describes the aluminium sources the company procures and uses for aluminium profile products [2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: This SRM is part of the company’s core metal input (not an auxiliary material): the average-profile EPD reports about 40% recycled aluminium scrap in the declared profile, the company publicly states a high recycled percentage, and the site has large extrusion capacity (30,000 t/year). The low-carbon EPD variant being 100% primary aluminium indicates portfolio variation, not absence of SRM use [1][3][4][5].

share.context: Average-profile EPD states the declared end product consists of approximately 40% recycled aluminium (aluminium scrap); this is used as a product-level recycled-content share, with study year 2021 from the same EPD [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No company-wide annual mass of recycled aluminium input was disclosed in the accessed sources. The strongest quantification is a product-level recycled-content share (~40%) in the average-profile EPD; the 30,000 t/year figure is total extrusion capacity, not recycled input tonnage [3][5].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The ~40% recycled share is an average-profile EPD value (study year 2021) and may not represent the current company-wide mix. A separate low-carbon profile EPD shows a 100% primary-aluminium variant [3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The retrieved Norske Utslipp company page confirms a permit link exists, but the retrieved HTML page itself does not expose permit clauses on inbound material inputs, so this assessment is not permit-clause-based [6].
No current site-wide purchased/received tonnage of recycled aluminium input was found in the accessed website or EPD sources; only product-level composition/share evidence was found [1][3][5].
Product mix variability is material for aggregation: one EPD (average profile) includes ~40% recycled aluminium, while another (low-carbon profile) is modeled as 100% primary aluminium [3][4].

evidence.claim: EPD confirms the organization number for Raufoss Aluminium AS.

company.entity_resolution_notes: The legal entity is identified as REC Solar Norway AS with organization number 986 707 328 in its EPD documentation [2]. A later Elkem notice states Elkem Testvirksomhet AS was "formerly known as Rec Solar Norway AS," indicating post-transaction renaming/merger context [4]. Accessible Proff hits referred to subunit/renamed entries (not a clear standalone REC Solar Norway AS legal-entity profile), so proff_url is set to null [5].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: REC Solar Norway AS shows evidence of inbound secondary silicon feedstock in EPD data for solar-grade silicon: internally sourced recycled silicon (25.5%) and externally sourced recycled silicon (2.6%) [3]. This indicates meaningful SRM use in feedstock mix, but available evidence is percentage-based and historical, without recent annual tonnage [3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled silicon feedstock
material_examples: Internally sourced recycled Si (bottom- and top cuts)
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as input feedstock in manufacturing solar grade silicon (SoG-Si) [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: EPD data reports 25.5% internally sourced recycled Si and 2.6% externally sourced recycled Si in the total SoG-Si mass, indicating meaningful SRM input share [3].

share.context: The SoG-Si EPD table reports 25.5% internal recycled silicon plus 2.6% external recycled silicon in total mass [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct annual SRM tonnage is provided in accessible sources; quantification is provided as share percentages in EPD tables [3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The EPD percentages are based on declared-product data and may not represent current operations after ownership changes and merger/dissolution steps in 2024 [3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No directly reported annual mass of recycled silicon input (t/year) was found in accessible documents; only percentage shares were available [3].
Entity structure changed after 2024 transactions, which may affect continuity/comparability of SRM input reporting for the same legal entity [4].
Permit material confirms production/NACE context but does not quantify SRM inbound feedstocks [1].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Entity resolved as the Norwegian legal company RETURKRAFT AS (org. no. 991590463) via Proff and company website footer.[1][2] The permit document is for the same site/operator but shows facility business number 991630538, which is distinct from legal org number.[3]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Returkraft’s core activity is energy recovery from incoming residual waste; the plant receives residual waste from households/businesses and burns it for electricity and district heating.[2][3] Public sources show large inbound volumes (about 130,000 t/year handled; permit framework up to 160,000 t/year), indicating significant/core SRM input use.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Residual waste as solid recovered fuel for energy recovery
material_examples: Special waste fractions sent to incineration
srm_inputs.used_for: Incoming residual waste is combusted in the plant to recover energy as electricity and district heating.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes annual handling of ~130,000 tonnes of residual/special waste and the permit allows very large waste intake for incineration, showing this is a core input stream.[2][3]

main_quantity.context: Company page states annual handled volume of residual and special waste.[2]

other_quantities.context: Permit states maximum total annual waste intake at the plant.[3]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct annual inbound amount is publicly stated on the company page (130,000 t/year), while permit limit is higher (160,000 t/year).[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 130,000 t figure is not explicitly tied to one named reporting year in the page text, and it aggregates residual plus special waste types.[2]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No machine-readable annual report table was accessible here to confirm a year-specific actual inbound tonnage split by waste category.[2]
Permit provides a legal maximum intake (not actual realized intake), so it is treated as permit_limit, not actual use.[3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity fields were used as instructed; the company website branding and footer address align with the provided company identity, and no discrepancy was found [1][2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: The company’s website explicitly states that secondary aluminum (recycled aluminum) is used as its raw material and describes recycled/raw-material recycling practices in its aluminum casting service, indicating a core inbound SRM metal input (A3). No quantitative input volumes or shares are disclosed on the reviewed pages [3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Secondary aluminum (recycled aluminum / secondary alloys)
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as raw material/feedstock in the company’s aluminum casting production (including die casting and mold casting of aluminum components) [3][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company states that its raw material is recovered from previous aluminum products and says remelted alloys are prepared by suppliers for use “hos oss,” which supports recycled aluminum as a core production input rather than a minor pilot [3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: The reviewed company pages provide qualitative statements about recycled aluminum/raw-material recycling but do not disclose tonnage, annual purchase volumes, or feedstock shares [3][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The evidence is qualitative and primarily about aluminum. The company also produces zinc products, but the reviewed pages do not confirm whether zinc feedstock is recycled/secondary [2][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed website pages do not provide aggregation-ready quantities (mass/volume/energy) or percentage shares for recycled aluminum inputs [3][4].
The company’s public pages mention production of both aluminum and zinc products, but only aluminum has explicit recycled-input statements in the reviewed sources [2][3][4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity was used as instructed; reviewed sources show SCHUTZ NORDIC AS on Proff and SCHÜTZ Nordic AS on company pages, with no material discrepancy identified [2][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: SCHÜTZ Nordic describes a closed-loop packaging system and, for the Kongsvinger subsidiary, states that returned packaging is collected/reconditioned, processed into regranulate, and used to produce new packaging and pallets; it also describes Green Layer products with 30% recycled material [1][2].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastic (HDPE recyclate/regranulate and recycled pellets) from returned packaging
srm_inputs.used_for: Returned empty packaging is collected via SCHÜTZ's reconditioning service, reprocessed into regranulate in SCHÜTZ's recycling center, and used as input for new packaging and pallets; recycled pellets are also used in the middle layer of Green Layer inner bottles [1][2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The evidence shows established (not pilot) closed-loop collection/reconditioning and direct use of recycled plastic feedstock in production, including a marketed Green Layer product line with a stated recycled-content share, but no company-wide inbound tonnage is disclosed [1][2].

share.context: The press article states Green Layer packaging is made from 30 percent recycled material and explains recycled pellets are used in the inner bottle middle layer [1].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Reviewed public sources describe the recycled-plastic input process and a product-level recycled-content share, but they do not disclose annual mass/volume of recycled plastic input for SCHUTZ NORDIC AS [1][2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 30% figure is a product-level recycled-content statement (Green Layer inner-bottle construction), not a disclosed company-wide share of all inbound plastic inputs at Kongsvinger [1].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No annual tonnage (t/year) for HDPE recyclate/regranulate or recycled pellets used by SCHUTZ NORDIC AS was identified in the reviewed public sources [1][2].
The reviewed sources describe closed-loop processes and product composition, but do not quantify what share of total Kongsvinger production volume uses recycled-plastic inputs [1][2].
No public permit/report figures were identified in this review that quantify inbound recycled-plastic input volumes for the Norwegian site [1][2].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity is consistent with BRREG (SIMONA STADPIPE AS, org. no. 981 928 652) and the company website branding/operations pages; no material discrepancy affecting entity resolution was found.[5][1]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: SIMONA Stadpipe clearly operates production of PE-based piping systems, but the only inbound SRM signal found is a SIMONA Group annual-report statement that welding-wire coils were switched to recycled plastic in a paragraph introduced with SIMONA Stadpipe; no site-specific recycled polymer feedstock quantities were found for Stadpipe.[1][2][3][4]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastic welding-wire coils (auxiliary input)
material_examples: Recycled-plastic coils/spools used for supplied welding wire
srm_inputs.used_for: The evidence indicates recycled-plastic coils used as the supply format for welding wire, relevant to pipe/fitting welding activities; company pages describe PE pipe/electrofusion welding and in-house production of PE modules.[2][3][4]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: This appears to be a real inbound recycled-plastic input, but it is an auxiliary production/packaging component (wire coils), not a demonstrated core pipe/feedstock raw material. Attribution to Stadpipe is plausible from the paragraph context but not explicitly isolated to the site.[4]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No mass, volume, energy, or share data for recycled plastic input was disclosed for Stadpipe. The only quantified datapoint found is a count of 100,000 welding-wire coils per year at SIMONA level, which cannot be stored in the allowed unit set and may not be Stadpipe-only.[4]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The annual-report wording links the example to a paragraph introduced with SIMONA Stadpipe, but the recycled-plastic coil measure may be reported at broader SIMONA scope. The evidence also concerns an auxiliary coil/spool input rather than polymer feedstock for pipes/fittings.[4][2][3]

gaps_and_uncertainties: The company website sustainability text mainly describes recyclability of products and recycling of collected end caps/residual waste (waste outflow), which is excluded from SRM-input assessment.[1]
No accessible company-page or registry evidence found in this run quantifies inbound recycled polymer share/tonnage in Stadpipe's pipe/fitting production inputs.[1][2][3][5]
The only quantified recycled-input signal found (100,000 welding-wire coils/year) is reported in the SIMONA Group annual report and is not explicitly assigned to SIMONA Stadpipe alone.[4]

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity was retained as instructed; reviewed Skanem website pages repeatedly reference "Skanem Bergen AS" and Bergen-specific operations, and no conflicting identity information was found [2][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Skanem Bergen has site-specific evidence of ISCC PLUS certification and authorization to produce products using chemically recycled materials, indicating inbound recycled-plastic capability at the Bergen site [2][3]. Separate Skanem Norway product-page evidence states use of post-consumer recycled (PCR) materials in production for thin wall packaging, and Skanem Bergen is described on the quality page as active in the same laundry-capsule/thin-wall packaging segment, but direct Bergen production attribution remains inferential [3][4]. No Bergen-specific inbound SRM volumes or annual purchased quantities were disclosed in the reviewed sources [2][3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Chemically recycled plastic materials for packaging production
srm_inputs.used_for: A Skanem Bergen news article states the Bergen site is authorized to produce products using chemically recycled materials following ISCC PLUS certification [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence is site-specific and relevant to recycled-plastic inputs, but it documents authorization/capability rather than disclosed recurring consumption volumes or confirmed realized input use, so a minor/capability-stage tier is most defensible [2][3].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No Bergen-specific tonnage, purchased quantity, or product-mix share for chemically recycled materials is disclosed in the reviewed article or quality page [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The wording confirms authorization to use chemically recycled materials at Skanem Bergen, but it does not quantify or confirm realized annual input consumption [2].

srm_inputs.label: Post-consumer recycled (PCR) plastic in thin wall packaging production
srm_inputs.used_for: A Skanem Norway product page for "Thin wall packaging with PCR materials" states use of post-consumer recycled materials in production, while Skanem Bergen's quality page describes Bergen in the same laundry-capsule/thin-wall packaging segment [3][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The product page contains explicit PCR-use language, but it is scoped as "Skanem Norway" and does not explicitly name Bergen as the manufacturing site for the PCR product page content, so Bergen attribution is inferred and should remain low-confidence [3][4].

share.context: The product page states capability to produce PCR inclusion levels "up to 100%"; this is a product-level capability share, not a disclosed realized Bergen input share [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Reviewed sources provide PCR capability language and product-level percentage capability (up to 100%) but no Bergen-specific production volumes, purchases, or adoption rates for PCR inputs [3][4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The PCR statements are on a Skanem Norway product page; Bergen linkage is inferred from matching segment descriptions (laundry capsules/thin wall packaging) on Skanem Bergen's quality page [3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No reviewed source discloses Bergen-specific annual tonnage, purchased quantities, or site-level shares of recycled plastic inputs [2][3][4].
No annual report, sustainability report, or ESG report with Bergen-level SRM input metrics was identified in the reviewed sources used here [2][3][4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Entity resolved as Norwegian legal company SPEIRA AS (org.nr. 975 934 578) via Proff. Speira’s 2024 Transparency Act statement confirms Speira AS is one of the two Speira Norway operating companies and has facilities in Holmestrand and Karmøy. [1][2]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Speira AS uses recycled aluminium scrap as an inbound production input, with Holmestrand described as producing rolled aluminium products based on remelting recycled and primary aluminium, and 'almost exclusively' on scrap plus ingot metal in the transparency statement. However, full company-wide actual SRM input tonnage is not disclosed in the located sources. [2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminium scrap
srm_inputs.used_for: Input feed for remelting/casting in the Holmestrand foundry to produce rolled aluminium products. [2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates substantial use at Holmestrand (including language that production there is almost exclusively based on remelting aluminium scrap and ingot metal), but the legal entity has multiple sites and no audited company-wide SRM input share/tonnage is provided in the retrieved set. [2][3][4]

other_quantities.context: Company press communication states the new Holmestrand furnace will add 22,000 tons scrap intake per year; this is a forward-looking increase, not reported historical actual use. [4]

share.context: Press communication says around half of Holmestrand production will be based on recycled scrap after the new furnace project. [4]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No source found with current, company-level actual annual SRM input mass for Speira AS; available quantified figures are forward-looking site-level statements for Holmestrand. [4]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The transparency statement is common reporting context for Speira AS and Speira Recycling Services Norway AS, and the strongest scrap-use wording is site-specific (Holmestrand). Forward-looking figures may change as the furnace project progresses. [2][4]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No retrieved annual report/ESG dataset provided audited, current-year company-level tonnes of recycled scrap input for Speira AS alone. [2][4]
Permit-hearing text confirms recycled aluminium remelting and expected higher scrap intake, but does not provide realized annual SRM mass for the legal entity. [3]

employees.notes: Used the pre-filled prompt metadata (Proff-derived) directly and did not re-verify during this run [4].

revenue.notes: Used the pre-filled prompt metadata (Proff-derived) directly and did not re-verify during this run [4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled company identity was retained. The permit evidence covers a Speira Recycling Services aluminium recycling site at Rød and a legacy REAL ALLOY saltslagg recycling permit at Raudsand; Speira states the acquired Norwegian aluminium and saltslagg recycling plants were integrated into Recycling Services [1][2][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence from norskeutslipp permits shows inbound secondary aluminium residues/scrap and saltslagg are core inputs to Speira-linked recycling/remelting activities at Rød and Raudsand. Available volumes are permit limits (not confirmed actual throughput), but they are large enough to indicate significant/core SRM use [1][2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Aluminium dross and aluminium scrap for remelting (Rød)
srm_inputs.used_for: The Rød permit states the activity includes remelting and lists inbound aluminium skimming/dross and aluminium scrap fractions under the permit frame [1].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: This is a core site input stream because the permit frame lists three aluminium residue/scrap remelting fractions with a combined permitted limit of 100,000 t/year (70,000 + 20,000 + 10,000) [1].

main_quantity.context: Permit-limit quantity for the aluminium skimming/dross remelting input fraction at the Rød site (2025 permit revision) [1].

other_quantities.context: Permit-limit quantity for uncoated aluminium scrap listed in the same Rød remelting input table text [1].
Permit-limit quantity for coated/lacquered aluminium scrap listed in the same Rød remelting input table text [1].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The quantities are permit limits for inbound remelting fractions at the Rød site, not reported actual annual receipts/consumption [1].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The permit confirms allowed inbound fractions and limits, but not realized throughput, yield, or whether some residues are transferred internally to other Speira/related facilities [1][2].

srm_inputs.label: Salt slag from secondary aluminium production (Raudsand)
srm_inputs.used_for: The Raudsand permit covers receipt, storage, and treatment of hazardous waste and explicitly lists salt slag from secondary production for mechanical treatment, wet treatment, and separation [2].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Salt slag treatment is a core Recycling Services activity at the Raudsand site because the permit allows up to 50,000 t/year treatment and Speira describes a Norwegian salt slag recycling plant integrated into Recycling Services [2][3].

main_quantity.context: Permit-limit annual treatment quantity for salt slag from secondary production at Raudsand (mechanical/wet treatment and separation) [2].

other_quantities.context: Permit-limit storage quantity (at any one time) for salt slag from secondary production in Raudsand permit annex table [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The 50,000 t figure is a permit treatment limit and the 7,000 t figure is a storage limit, so they should not be interpreted as actual annual realized intake [2].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Permit evidence is site-level and partly under a legacy REAL ALLOY permit name; mapping to the pre-filled legal entity relies on Speira's acquisition/integration context and the pre-matched permit list [2][3][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No company-level annual report or public operating dataset was found in this run that states actual yearly inbound SRM tonnages, so quantities are recorded as permit limits only [1][2].
The evidence is primarily site-permit based (Rød and Raudsand), which may not map one-to-one to the pre-filled legal entity's org number and may include legacy-entity naming [1][2][3][4].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Resolved to the Norwegian legal entity ST1 BIOKRAFT AS (AS) with org. no. 894625902 via Proff official company data.[1] Norskeutslipp also lists Biokraft AS (St1 biokraft as) in Levanger with permits (2019, 2023), consistent with the same Norwegian operating entity/site context.[4]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: ST1 Biokraft AS uses waste/residual organic inputs as core inbound feedstock for biogas at Skogn, including fish silage, sewage sludge/food waste context, and industrial process water side-streams.[2][3] Reported inbound handling volume is very large (914,906 tonnes for organic waste/residues/process water in 2023, Business Area Norway), indicating significant SRM dependence.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Organic bio-based residues for anaerobic digestion
srm_inputs.used_for: These residual organic substrates are fed into anaerobic digestion/biogas production at Skogn, where silage from salmon farms is described as a main raw material and sewage sludge/food waste are common substrates in Norway operations.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company describes these as primary/common substrates and reports very high annual managed inbound volume for organic waste/residues/process water (914,906 tonnes, Norway business area, 2023), supporting a core role.[2]

main_quantity.context: The disclosed figure is presented as "management of organic waste, residues and process water" for Norway/Skogn context; it is used as inbound SRM proxy volume.[2]

other_quantities.context: The Skogn production-page description states fish silage at 70,000 tonnes per year as a primary raw material.[3]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct total inbound mass is available, but it is aggregated together with process water and does not split each substrate type.[2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Public sources reviewed do not provide audited substrate-by-substrate annual tonnage split for the Norwegian legal entity alone.[2][3]

srm_inputs.label: Industrial process water side-stream input
material_examples: Process water from pulp and paper industry
srm_inputs.used_for: Process water from Norske Skog's pulp/paper industry is described as a primary raw material input in Skogn biogas production.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: It is explicitly named as primary raw material, indicating meaningful use, but no standalone annual tonnage is publicly disclosed in the reviewed sources.[2][3]
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No separate quantitative figure for process-water input alone was found in the reviewed company public materials.[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The available mass disclosure aggregates process water with other organic inputs, preventing exact A10-only quantification.[2]

gaps_and_uncertainties: Norskeutslipp indicates permits for Biokraft/St1 Biokraft (2019, 2023), but the underlying permit documents were not accessible in the retrieved pages for extracting permit-limit substrate breakdown.[4]
Public disclosures are mainly at Skogn/Norway business-area level; legal-entity-only SRM split by input stream remains limited.[2][3]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Steen-Hansen documents use of copper oxide made from recycled copper pipes/wires/refrigerators in its copper-based net protection products, indicating meaningful inbound SRM metal input use in that product line.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No public numeric data (mass, volume, energy, or share) was found for recycled copper-derived input volumes in available company pages.[2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Evidence confirms recycled origin of the copper oxide input but does not quantify company-wide consumption or portfolio share.[2]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No annual report/sustainability report with quantified SRM input tonnage was found in the reviewed sources.[1][2]
Available evidence is product-line specific (copper-based products) and may not represent all company product families (e.g., copper-free lines).[2]

company.entity_resolution_notes: No material discrepancy was found: the company website identifies Stenqvist AS in Drammen and describes plastic/paper bag production; org number and NACE were retained from the pre-filled metadata [1][6].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Stenqvist AS (Drammen) publicly offers Norwegian packaging products made with recycled plastic (including PCR plastic and an 80% recycled-content dog-bag product) and paper sacks available in recycled paper, indicating inbound SRM use of recycled polymers and recycled fiber. However, no company-level annual SRM input volumes or shares for Norwegian operations were found; the reviewed norskeutslipp permit is focused on air/VOC emissions rather than recycled raw-material quantities [1][2][3][4][5].

srm_inputs.label: Reprocessed plastic polymers (PCR/recycled PE)
srm_inputs.used_for: Norwegian Stenqvist product pages describe bag products made with recycled/PCR plastic, including green products and dog-poop bags, implying recycled polymer input in packaging production/offering [1][2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: There is direct evidence of recycled-plastic content in named products (including 80% recycled content in one product and up to 90% PCR in several green products), but no evidence of company-level usage volumes or how much of total Norwegian production uses these inputs [2][3].

share.context: A Norwegian dog-poop bag product page states 80% recycled material in PE, which is treated as a product-level recycled-content share rather than a company-wide input share [2].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct company-level tonnage, purchased volume, or annual recycled-polymer input quantity was disclosed. Available quantification is limited to product-level recycled-content claims (80% on one product; up to 90% PCR on several green products) [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The pages are product/marketing pages and do not state whether the recycled-plastic products are all produced at the Drammen site versus elsewhere in the group, nor the share of total Norwegian output they represent [1][2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled paper fibers
srm_inputs.used_for: A Norwegian product page for paper sacks states they are produced in both virgin paper and recycled paper, indicating recycled fiber as an inbound material option for paper sack products [1][4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The website directly confirms recycled paper use as a product material option, but no company-level consumption volume, share, or frequency is disclosed [4].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No quantitative information (tonnes, annual consumption, or product mix share) for recycled paper inputs was found on the reviewed sources [4][5].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The statement confirms availability/production in recycled paper but does not quantify actual usage in Norwegian operations or identify which site(s) produce the sacks [1][4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The reviewed norskeutslipp permit is an air-emission/VOC permit and does not provide recycled raw-material input quantities or annual inbound SRM data [5].
Stenqvist product pages confirm recycled-material use/options, but they do not disclose total Norwegian production share, annual SRM tonnage, or purchase volumes [2][3][4].
Employees and revenue were taken from the pre-filled prompt metadata (Proff-derived) without an explicit reporting year in the input [6].

enrichment.description: Utførelse av undervannskonstruksjons- og vedlikeholdsarbeider, geotekniske og geofysiske undersøkelser, fjerning av utrangerte undervannsinstallasjoner og/eller offshoreinstallasjoner inklusiv tilhørende avfallstransport og avfallsmegling og andre typer arbeider for offshoreindustrien så vel på den norske kontinentalsokkel som internasjonalt. Selskapets formål er videre å eie og drive skip, drive skipsmeglingsvirksomhet, assuransevirksomhet, investeringer i fast eiendom, samt deltagelse i andre selskaper av enhver art enten ved aksjekjøp eller på annen måte, samt å avgi garantier og annen sikkerhetsstillelse i forbindelse med selskapets virksomhet, herunder avgi garantier og stille sikkerhet for selskaper innenfor samme konsern som selskapet tilhører.

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity is consistent with the reviewed sources: the Sundolitt page footer shows "Sunde AS", while the norskeutslipp permit uses the historical name "Brødrene Sunde AS" but matches org number 916416784 [1][2][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Sunde AS has clear evidence of inbound secondary plastic input use (recycled/reused polystyrene) in branded product lines: a 50% recycled/reused-content XPS offer and EPS products documented with 30% recycled polystyrene via mass balance. However, no company-wide annual SRM tonnage was disclosed in the reviewed sources [3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled/reused polystyrene input for XPS products (Sundolitt XPS 2nd Life 50)
srm_inputs.used_for: The company states collected EPS is recycled/reused into polystyrene that is then used for XPS production or new raw material, and markets an XPS product line with recycled/reused content [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence indicates a meaningful product-line application: the page states 50% recycled/reused material is blended into all XPS products (listed across pressure classes), but no company-level consumption volumes are provided [3].

share.context: Product-level share based on the Sundolitt 2nd Life page statement that XPS 2nd Life 50 contains 50% recycled/reused material in all XPS products (pressure classes 250-700 kPa) [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct mass or annual volume of recycled polystyrene input is disclosed on the reviewed page; only percentage content and process descriptions are provided [3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The claim is product-line specific and does not disclose actual annual production mix or site-specific realized recycled-input consumption for Sunde AS [3].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled polystyrene input for EPS 2nd Life 30 products (mass-balance documented)
srm_inputs.used_for: Under the 2nd Life concept, used polystyrene products are collected, recovered, and used in the production of new products; the page documents EPS products with recycled polystyrene content [4].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The Sunde EPS page documents a 30% recycling rate and gives a specific example (Sunde Arctic 2nd Life 30-284) with 30% recycled polystyrene, indicating recurring productized use rather than a one-off pilot [4].

share.context: Mass-balance product-content example on the Sunde EPS page states Sunde Arctic 2nd Life 30-284 contains 30% recycled polystyrene [4].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: The reviewed product page provides percentage-based recycled-content claims but no annual tonnage of recycled polystyrene input [4].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 30% figure is documented via mass-balance and a product example; the page does not state company-wide average recycled content across all EPS production [4].

gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed company pages provide product-level recycled-content percentages (30% and 50%) but no company-wide annual recycled-polystyrene input tonnage for Sunde AS [3][4].
The reviewed norskeutslipp permit confirms EPS/PS production scale and identity, but it does not quantify actual secondary raw material feedstock usage [2].
The permit is dated 2010 and uses the historical name "Brødrene Sunde AS" plus an older NACE classification, so it is not suitable to confirm the current pre-filled NACE codes [2].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Pre-filled identity fields were used as instructed; reviewed Tepas Industrier website pages show the same company name and org. number, and no discrepancy was observed [2][3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Based on reviewed Tepas Industrier website pages, the company is described as a metal fabrication / powder-coating producer working in steel, aluminium and stainless materials; reviewed pages mention internal powder recovery and excess-heat use plus waste sorting, but do not document external recycled/recovered/waste-derived input materials or taxonomy-listed SRM fuels as inbound inputs [2][3][4][5].
gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed public pages do not disclose recycled content, scrap-metal procurement, or supplier specifications for steel/aluminium/coating materials, so SRM input use may exist but is not evidenced here [2][3][4].

Miljøfyrtårn content mentions overskuddsvarme and waste return arrangements, and the powder-coating page mentions powder recovery, but these appear to be internal recovery / waste-management practices rather than clearly documented external inbound SRM inputs under the provided taxonomy [4][5].
