srm_assessment.overall_summary: TINE discloses inbound use of recycled plastic as a packaging input. In 2024, average recycled plastic share in plastic packaging was 4.5%, with 50% recycled content introduced in some cups.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastic in product packaging
material_examples: Recycled plastic in cultured milk cups
Recycled plastic content in yogurt packaging
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as inbound packaging material for dairy products, including cultured milk cups and yogurt-related packaging formats.[2]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company reports implemented recycled-plastic input use, but the disclosed portfolio average is 4.5%, indicating minor (not yet dominant) SRM penetration.[2]

share.context: Disclosed as the 2024 average share of recycled plastic in plastic packaging for company products.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: No direct mass quantity (t/kg) of recycled plastic input is disclosed in the reviewed source; only percentage shares are provided.[2]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: One statement combines 'resirkulert og fornybar plast' (90%), so the purely recycled fraction is not fully isolated for that packaging line.[2]

gaps_and_uncertainties: Available disclosures provide recycled-content percentages, but not annual inbound SRM mass suitable for direct aggregation.[2]
No additional inbound SRM input category (beyond recycled plastic packaging) was quantified in the reviewed annual report and packaging disclosure.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Proff profile titled "Ulefos Jernv�e6rk AS" shows legal name "ULEFOS AS" with org number 981 083 032.[1] The EPD owner is also Ulefos AS with org. no. 981083032.[2] Norskeutslipp lists the facility name Ulefos Jernv�e6rk AS with permit references, consistent with facility naming under the same entity context.[4]

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence indicates scrap iron is a core inbound input. A company page states scrap iron is the raw material used in production and reports 11,000 tons/year.[3] The EPD composition shows 93.23% scrap iron in declared ductile iron product mass.[2]

srm_inputs.label: Ferrous scrap iron
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as the main metallic input for producing ductile iron products at Ulefos Jernv�e6rk.[2][3]
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The company states 11,000 tons of scrap are used per year in production, and the EPD shows scrap iron at 93.23% of product material mass, indicating core dependence.[2][3]

main_quantity.context: Company communication explicitly states annual scrap tonnage used in production.[3]

other_quantities.context: EPD material table for declared unit (1 ton) lists scrap iron mass input.[2]

share.context: EPD composition table reports scrap iron share in product mass.[2]

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A company-level annual amount is reported on a website article (11,000 t/year), while EPD gives product-level composition per declared unit (1 ton).[2][3]
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The annual 11,000 t figure is from a company webpage and not tied to a clearly stated reporting year in the snippet.[3] The EPD is prospective and references earlier underlying data.[2]

gaps_and_uncertainties: No accessible permit text excerpt was retrieved to cross-validate inbound scrap quantities; only Norskeutslipp permit listing metadata was accessible here.[4]
SRM quantification is split between company-level annual statement and product-level EPD composition, limiting exact year-aligned aggregation.[2][3]

company.entity_resolution_notes: The company website contact page matches the provided legal name and Kristiansand address, but UAC’s 2024 sustainability report lists a different org. number (991865692) and a different NACE classification (C.22.23); this appears to be an internal reporting inconsistency, so the pre-filled identity/NACE values were retained as ground truth [1][3][4].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed company sources disclose conventional raw materials for composite pressure vessels (HDPE components, stainless steel, glass fibre, resin/hardener) and aggregate material-input totals, but no explicit recycled, recovered, reused, or waste-derived input factors were identified for UAC’s own production activities [1][2].
gaps_and_uncertainties: The 2024 sustainability report reports total material input and a renewable/non-renewable split, but it does not specify whether any share is recycled/recovered secondary material [1].
UAC’s circularity wording refers to inputs being "renewable and recyclable," which indicates material characteristics/potential end-of-life handling rather than confirmed secondary-content use [1].

Product pages describe constituent materials (plastic liner, stainless steel, fibreglass, epoxy resin) but provide no recycled-content percentages, supplier provenance, or waste-derived feedstock disclosures [2].
The report discloses purchased grid electricity (including renewable electricity volume), but no biomass fuel or biogas use as an internal energy input is stated in the reviewed sources [1].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The Proff page is a unit page, but it explicitly points to the main entity (hovedenhet) VEIDEKKE INDUSTRI AS with organization number 913 536 770; this was used as the legal-entity anchor [1]. Statsforvalteren also names Veidekke Industri AS directly for asphalt/returasfalt operations [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Veidekke Industri AS has documented inbound use of reclaimed asphalt (returasfalt) as an input to asphalt production. A Statsforvalteren case states receipt/crushing of up to 5,000 tonnes annually for reuse in its asphalt production, and Veidekke discloses major projects where about half of asphalt volume contains recycled asphalt [2][3].

srm_inputs.label: Reclaimed asphalt (returasfalt)
material_examples: Crushed recycled asphalt from old road sections
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as recycled mineral/asphalt input in new asphalt production at Veidekke asphalt plants [2][3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: Evidence shows explicit operational reuse in asphalt production and large-project deployment with substantial recycled share; this indicates meaningful SRM use rather than only pilot activity [2][3].

main_quantity.context: A Statsforvalteren hearing text states an application for receiving/crushing up to 5,000 tonnes returasfalt annually for reuse in asphalt production at Sigerfjord [2].

share.context: For a major E10 contract, Veidekke states about half of asphalt volume will contain recycled asphalt from the old road section [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Direct company-wide SRM intake totals were not found; available quantified evidence is site/project specific (5,000 t/year application in Sortland and ~50% recycled share in an E10 project) [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The 5,000 t figure is from a hearing/application text and not a confirmed measured annual intake. The E10 disclosure is a Veidekke group press release and does not explicitly name the legal entity in the quote [2][3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: No consolidated annual tonnage of recycled asphalt input for the full legal entity was located in accessible public sources [2][3].
No directly accessible annual/sustainability PDF table for Veidekke Industri AS with entity-level SRM input breakdown was retrievable from the crawled sources [3].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Reviewed public company pages describe sheltered work/training and production tasks (including aluminium processing, staining, carpentry/woodwork, and firewood-related work), but no reviewed page provides explicit evidence of recycled, reused, or waste-derived materials or energy used as inbound inputs [2][4][5][6][7].
gaps_and_uncertainties: Reviewed website pages describe activities and processing tasks but do not disclose raw-material origin, recycled content, or energy sourcing, so inbound SRM use cannot be confirmed from public sources reviewed here [2][4][5][6][7].
The firewood service page appears incomplete (placeholder text), which limits assessment of whether biomass inputs include reclaimed or waste-derived wood [8].

revenue.notes: Proff reports operating revenue as 19 398 454 with "Beløp i 1000", converted to NOK by multiplying by 1,000 [1].

company.entity_resolution_notes: Matched the Norwegian legal entity by exact legal name and organization number on Proff [1]. Yara Norge AS also states its transparency disclosure refers to Yara International ASA's integrated disclosure, which is used as supporting SRM context [2].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Evidence indicates meaningful SRM input use in Yara's integrated reporting (byproduct/waste-stream raw materials and recycled plastic packaging), but the report does not provide a Yara Norge AS-only split [2][3]. Therefore, SRM is assessed as meaningful with entity-level uncertainty [3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Byproduct and waste-stream chemical raw materials
material_examples: Ammonium sulphate byproduct from synthetic fiber production
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as inbound raw materials in production (group-reported), including sulfur and ammonium sulphate byproduct inputs [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The integrated report states 1,933 thousand tonnes of byproduct/waste-stream raw materials and 21.5% of raw material inflows (excluding feedstock), indicating meaningful use, but not disaggregated to Yara Norge AS [3].

main_quantity.context: Reported as procured raw materials based on byproducts or waste streams from suppliers in 2024 [3].

share.context: Share is reported as percent of raw material inflows excluding feedstock [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: Quantity and share are explicitly reported, but at Yara integrated-report scope rather than legal-entity level for Yara Norge AS [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: No explicit split by Norwegian legal entity, site, or business unit is provided for these byproduct/waste-stream inputs [3][4].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled plastic used in product packaging
srm_inputs.used_for: Used as inbound packaging material for Yara product bags in Europe [3].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The report documents implementation (30% recycled plastic bags in Europe; 4,427 tonnes recycled plastic in 2024), but this is packaging input and not disclosed specifically for Yara Norge AS [3].

main_quantity.context: Reported recycled plastic use in 2024 related to packaging initiatives [3].

share.context: Report states all bags in Europe were changed to 30% recycled plastic [3].

srm_inputs.volume_notes: A direct mass quantity exists, but entity-level allocation to Yara Norge AS is not disclosed [2][3].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: Geographic statement is Europe-wide and may include operations outside Norway; no site/entity allocation is provided [3].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The integrated report provides company-wide data, not a legal-entity breakdown for Yara Norge AS [2][3].
No permit/about-page evidence found that quantifies SRM inbound inputs specifically for Yara Porsgrunn or Yara Glomfjord [4].
SRM evidence is strongest for group-level procurement and packaging initiatives; applicability to Yara Norge AS is inferred but not directly quantified [2][3].

company.entity_resolution_notes: The pre-filled identity matches the company website footer (company name and Org.nr 928 738 302); only the input name appears to have an encoding artifact for the initial letter Ø [1].

srm_assessment.overall_summary: Østlandske Lettmetall explicitly states on its aluminium casting service page that it uses recycled aluminium in production, primarily from Hydro, but it does not publish SRM volumes or shares [1].

srm_inputs.label: Recycled aluminium
srm_inputs.used_for: The company states it uses recycled aluminium in its production, and the same page describes aluminium casting as a core production activity [1].
srm_inputs.tier_reasoning: The evidence shows ongoing use of recycled aluminium in production (not a pilot), but no quantitative share or annual input volume is disclosed, so core/significant reliance cannot be confirmed [1].
srm_inputs.volume_notes: No inbound recycled aluminium quantity, annual tonnage, or recycled-content share is disclosed on the reviewed company page [1].
srm_inputs.uncertainties: The source does not state whether all aluminium feedstock is recycled, which alloys are covered, or the proportion of recycled versus primary aluminium [1].

gaps_and_uncertainties: The company page confirms recycled aluminium use but omits SRM volumes and percentages needed for aggregation of actual inbound recycled metal quantities [1].
The page names Hydro as the primary source but provides no specification of recycled-content grade or supplier product type [1].
